
   
<EOS>
The
Workshop
  
<EOS>
With
a
single
drop
of
ink
for
a
mirror
,
the
Egyptian
sorcerer
undertakes
to
reveal
to
any
chance
comer
far
-
reaching
visions
of
the
past
.
<EOS>
This
is
what
I
undertake
to
do
for
you
,
reader
.
<EOS>
With
this
drop
of
ink
at
the
end
of
my
pen
,
I
will
show
you
the
roomy
workshop
of
Mr.
Jonathan
Burge
,
carpenter
and
builder
,
in
the
village
of
Hayslope
,
as
it
appeared
on
the
eighteenth
of
June
,
in
the
year
of
our
Lord
1799
.
  
<EOS>
The
afternoon
sun
was
warm
on
the
five
workmen
there
,
busy
upon
doors
and
window
-
frames
and
wainscoting
.
<EOS>
A
scent
of
pine
-
wood
from
a
tentlike
pile
of
planks
outside
the
open
door
mingled
itself
with
the
scent
of
the
elder
-
bushes
which
were
spreading
their
summer
snow
close
to
<EOS>
the
open
window
opposite
;
the
slanting
sunbeams
shone
through
the
transparent
shavings
that
flew
before
the
steady
plane
,
and
lit
up
the
fine
grain
of
the
oak
panelling
which
stood
propped
against
the
wall
.
<EOS>
On
a
heap
of
those
soft
shavings
a
rough
,
grey
shepherd
dog
had
made
himself
a
pleasant
bed
,
and
was
lying
with
his
nose
between
his
fore
-
paws
,
occasionally
wrinkling
his
brows
to
cast
a
glance
at
the
tallest
of
the
five
workmen
,
who
was
carving
a
shield
in
the
centre
of
a
wooden
mantelpiece
.
<EOS>
It
was
to
this
workman
that
the
strong
barytone
belonged
which
was
heard
above
the
sound
of
plane
and
hammer
singing
         
Awake
,
my
soul
,
and
with
the
sun
     
Thy
daily
stage
of
duty
run
;
     
Shake
off
dull
sloth
...
  
<EOS>
Here
some
measurement
was
to
be
taken
which
required
more
concentrated
attention
,
and
the
sonorous
voice
subsided
into
a
low
whistle
;
but
it
presently
broke
out
again
with
renewed
vigour
         
<EOS>
Let
all
thy
converse
be
sincere
,
     
Thy
conscience
as
the
noonday
clear
.
  
<EOS>
Such
a
voice
could
only
come
from
a
broad
chest
,
and
the
broad
chest
belonged
to
a
large
-
boned
,
muscular
man
nearly
six
feet
high
,
with
a
back
so
flat
and
a
head
<EOS>
so
well
poised
that
when
he
drew
himself
up
to
take
a
more
distant
survey
of
his
work
,
he
had
the
air
of
a
soldier
standing
at
ease
.
<EOS>
The
sleeve
rolled
up
above
the
elbow
<EOS>
showed
an
arm
that
was
likely
to
win
the
prize
for
feats
of
strength
;
yet
the
long
supple
hand
,
with
its
broad
finger
-
tips
,
looked
ready
for
works
of
skill
.
<EOS>
In
his
tall
stalwartness
Adam
Bede
was
a
Saxon
,
and
justified
his
name
;
but
the
jet
-
black
hair
,
made
the
more
noticeable
by
its
contrast
with
the
light
paper
cap
,
and
the
keen
glance
of
the
dark
eyes
that
shone
from
under
strongly
marked
,
prominent
and
mobile
eyebrows
,
indicated
a
mixture
of
Celtic
blood
.
<EOS>
The
face
was
large
and
roughly
hewn
,
and
when
in
repose
had
no
other
beauty
than
such
as
belongs
to
an
expression
of
good
-
humoured
honest
intelligence
.
  
<EOS>
It
is
clear
at
a
glance
that
the
next
workman
is
Adam
's
brother
.
<EOS>
He
is
nearly
as
tall
;
he
has
the
same
type
of
features
,
the
same
hue
of
hair
and
complexion
;
but
the
strength
of
the
family
likeness
seems
only
to
render
more
conspicuous
the
remarkable
difference
of
expression
both
in
form
and
face
.
<EOS>
Seth
's
broad
shoulders
have
a
slight
stoop
;
his
eyes
are
grey
;
his
eyebrows
have
less
prominence
and
more
repose
than
his
brother
's
;
and
his
glance
,
instead
of
being
keen
,
is
confiding
and
benign
.
<EOS>
He
has
thrown
off
his
paper
cap
,
and
you
see
that
his
hair
is
not
thick
and
straight
,
like
Adam
's
,
but
thin
and
wavy
,
allowing
you
to
discern
the
exact
contour
of
a
coronal
arch
that
predominates
very
decidedly
over
the
brow
.
  
<EOS>
The
idle
tramps
always
felt
sure
they
could
get
a
copper
from
Seth
;
they
scarcely
ever
spoke
to
Adam
.
  
<EOS>
The
concert
of
the
tools
and
Adam
's
voice
was
at
last
broken
by
Seth
,
who
,
lifting
the
door
at
which
he
had
been
working
intently
,
placed
it
against
the
wall
,
and
said
,
"
There
!
<EOS>
I
've
finished
my
door
to
-
day
,
anyhow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The
workmen
all
looked
up
;
Jim
Salt
,
a
burly
,
red
-
haired
man
known
as
Sandy
Jim
,
paused
from
his
planing
,
and
Adam
said
to
Seth
,
with
a
sharp
glance
of
surprise
,
"
<EOS>
What
!
<EOS>
Dost
think
thee'st
finished
the
door
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Aye
,
sure
,
"
said
Seth
,
with
answering
surprise
;
"
what
's
awanting
to't
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A
loud
roar
of
laughter
from
the
other
three
workmen
made
Seth
look
round
confusedly
.
<EOS>
Adam
did
not
join
in
the
laughter
,
but
there
was
a
slight
smile
on
his
face
as
he
said
,
in
a
gentler
tone
than
before
,
"
Why
,
thee'st
forgot
the
panels
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
laughter
burst
out
afresh
as
Seth
clapped
his
hands
to
his
head
,
and
coloured
over
brow
and
crown
.
  
<EOS>
"
Hoorray
!
"
shouted
a
small
lithe
fellow
called
Wiry
Ben
,
running
forward
and
seizing
the
door
.
<EOS>
"
We
'll
hang
up
th
'
door
at
fur
end
<EOS>
o
'
th
'
shop
an
'
write
on't
"
Seth
Bede
,
the
Methody
,
his
work
.
"
<EOS>
Here
,
Jim
,
lend
's
hould
o
'
th
'
red
pot
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Nonsense
!
"
said
Adam
.
<EOS>
"
Let
it
alone
,
Ben
Cranage
.
<EOS>
You
'll
mayhap
be
making
such
a
slip
yourself
some
day
;
you
'll
laugh
o
'
th
'
other
side
<EOS>
o
'

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Catch

,
Adam
.
<EOS>
It
'll
be
a
good
while
afore
my
head
's
full
o
'
th
'
Methodies
,
"
said
Ben
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nay
,
but
it
's
often
full
o
'
drink
,
and
that
's
worse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Ben
,
however
,
had
now
got
the
"
red
pot
"
in
his
hand
,
and
was
about
to
begin
writing
his
inscription
,
making
,
by
way
of
preliminary
,
an
imaginary
S
in
the
air
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
it
alone
,
will
you
?
"
<EOS>
Adam
called
out
,
laying
down
his
tools
,
striding
up
to
Ben
,
and
seizing
his
right
shoulder
.
<EOS>
"
Let
it
alone
,
or
I
'll
shake
the
soul
out
o
'
your
body
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Ben
shook
in
Adam
's
iron
grasp
,
but
,
like
a
plucky
small
man
as
he
was
,
he
did
n't
mean
to
give
in
.
<EOS>
With
his
left
hand
he
snatched
the
brush
from
his
powerless
right
,
and
made
a
movement
as
if
he
would
perform
the
feat
of
writing
with
his
left
.
<EOS>
In
a
moment
Adam
turned
him
round
,
seized
his
other
shoulder
,
and
,
pushing
him
along
,
pinned
him
against
the
wall
.
<EOS>
But
now
Seth
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
be
,
Addy
,
let
be
.
<EOS>
Ben
will
be
joking
.
<EOS>
Why
,
he
's
i
'
the
right
to
laugh
at
me
 
<EOS>
I
canna
help
laughing
at
myself
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
sha
n't
loose
him
till
he
promises
to
let
the
door
alone
,
"
said
Adam
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,
Ben
,
lad
,
"

,

,
"
do

's
have
a

about

.
<EOS>
You
know

.
<EOS>
You
may
's
well
try

a

in

.
<EOS>
Say

'll

the
door

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
binna
frighted

,
"

,
"
<EOS>
but
I
donna

sayin

as

'

alone
at

,
Seth
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Come
,

's
wise

,
Ben
,
"
said
Adam
,
laughing
and

.
  
<EOS>
They
all

to
their
work
now
;
but
Wiry
Ben
,
having
had
the
worst
in
the
bodily

,
was
bent

retrieving
that
humiliation
by

.
  
<EOS>
"
Which

'
on
,
Seth
,
"
he

"
the
pretty
parson
's
face
or

sarmunt
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Hitherto

!

"
Of

.
"
<EOS>
Poor

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

the

Adam
's

;
and
no

.
  
<EOS>
On

Adam

,
took

,

to

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

were

,
and

.
<EOS>
On

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

till

"

,

"

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Adam

long

,
Gyp
close
to

,
out

the
workyard
,
and
along

leading
away

and
down

.
<EOS>
As

reached

foot

,
an

,
with

behind

,
stopped
his
horse
when
Adam
had
passed

,
and
turned
round
to
have

look
at
the
stalwart
workman
in
paper
cap
,
leather

,
and
dark
-

.
  
<EOS>
Adam
,
unconscious
of
the
admiration
he
was
exciting
,
presently
struck
across
the
fields
,
and
now
broke
out
into
the
tune
which
had
all
day
long
been
running
in
his
head
:
       
<EOS>
Let
all
thy
converse
be
sincere
,
     
Thy
conscience
as
the
noonday
clear
;
     
For
God
's
all
-
seeing
eye
surveys
     
<EOS>
Thy
secret
thoughts
,
thy
works
and
ways
.
    
<EOS>
The
Preaching
  
About
a
quarter
to
seven
there
was
an
unusual
appearance
of
excitement
in
the
village
of
Hayslope
,
and
through
the
whole
length
of
its
little
street
,
from
the
Donnithorne
Arms
to
the
churchyard
gate
,
the
inhabitants
had
evidently
been
drawn
out
of
their
houses
by
something
more
than
the
pleasure
of
lounging
in
the
evening
sunshine
.
<EOS>
The
Donnithorne
Arms
stood
at
the
entrance
of
the
village
,
and
a
small
farmyard
and
stackyard
which
flanked
it
,
indicating
that
there
was
a
pretty
take
of
land
attached
to
the
inn
,
gave
the
traveller
a
promise
of
good
feed
for
himself
and
his
horse
,
which
might
well
console
him
for
the
ignorance
in
which
the
weather
-
beaten
sign
left
him
as
to
the
heraldic
bearings
of
that
ancient
family
,
the
Donnithornes
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Casson
,
the
landlord
,
had
been
for
some
time
standing
at
the
door
with
his
hands
in
his
pockets
,
balancing
himself
on
his
heels
and
toes
and
looking
towards
a
piece
of
unenclosed
ground
,
with
a
maple
in
the
middle
of
it
,
which
he
knew
to
be
the
destination
of
certain
grave
-
looking
men
and
women
whom
he
had
observed
passing
at
intervals
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Casson
's
person
was
by
no
means
of
that
common
type
which
can
be
allowed
to
pass
without
description
.
<EOS>
On
a
front
view
it
appeared
to
consist
principally
of
two
spheres
,
bearing
about
the
same
relation
to
each
other
as
the
earth
and
the
moon
:
that
is
to
say
,
the
lower
sphere
might
be
said
,
at
a
rough
guess
,
to
be
thirteen
times
larger
than
the
upper
which
naturally
performed
the
function
of
a
mere
satellite
and
tributary
.
<EOS>
But
here
the
resemblance
ceased
,
for
Mr.
Casson
's
head
was
not
at
all
a
melancholy
-
looking
satellite
nor
was
it
a
"
spotty
globe
,
"
as
Milton
has
irreverently
called
the
moon
;
on
the
contrary
,
no
head
and
face
could
look
more
sleek
and
healthy
,
and
its
expression
 
which
was
chiefly
confined
to
a
pair
of
round
and
ruddy
cheeks
,
the
slight
knot
and
interruptions
forming
the
nose
and
eyes
being
scarcely
worth
<EOS>
mention
 
<EOS>
was
one
of
jolly
contentment
,
only
tempered
by
that
sense
of
personal
dignity
which
usually
made
itself
felt
in
his
attitude
and
bearing
.
<EOS>
This
sense
of
dignity
could
hardly
be
considered
excessive
in
a
man
who
had
been
butler
to
"
the
family
"
for
fifteen
years
,
and
who
,
in
his
present
high
position
,
was
necessarily
very
much
in
contact
with
his
inferiors
.
<EOS>
How
to
reconcile
his
dignity
with
the
satisfaction
of
his
curiosity
by
walking
towards
the
Green
was
the
problem
that

Casson
had

<EOS>
The

,
but

Green
,

.
  
<EOS>
The
Green
lay
at
the

of
the
village
,
and
from
it
the
road
branched
off
in
two

,
one
leading
farther
up
the
hill
by

church
,
and
the
other

gently
down
towards
the

.
<EOS>
On
the
side
of
the
Green
that
led

,

broken

of
thatched

was
continued
nearly
to

;
but

side
,
there
was

to

of
gently

,
and

,
and

of
distant

.
<EOS>
That
rich
undulating
district
of
Loamshire
to
which
Hayslope
belonged
lies
close
to
a
grim
outskirt
of
Stonyshire
,
overlooked
by
its
barren

as
a
pretty

sister
may

;
and

'

,

,
for
one
where

under

,
or

,

;
and
where

every

came
upon
some
fine

-

nestled

the

or
crowning

,
some

with
its
long
length
of

and
its
cluster
of
golden

,
some
grey
steeple
looking
out
from
a
pretty
confusion
of
trees
and
thatch
and
dark
-
red

.
<EOS>
It
was
just
such
a
picture
as
this
last
that
Hayslope
Church
had
made
to
the
traveller
as

leading
to
its
pleasant

,
and
now

near

Green
he
had
before

in
one
view
<EOS>
nearly

other

of
this

.
<EOS>
High
up
against

were
the
huge

of
hill
,
like
giant
mounds
intended
to
fortify
this
region
of
corn
and
grass
against
the
keen
and

of
the
north
;
not
distant
enough
to
be
clothed
in
purple

,
but
with
sombre

sides
visibly

with
sheep
,
whose
motion
was
only
revealed
by
memory
,
not

by
sight
;
wooed
from
day

by
the
changing

,
but
responding
with
no

in
themselves
 
left
for
ever
grim
and

after

flush

,
the
winged

of
the
April

,

.
<EOS>
And

the

on

more

,
divided

,

,

.
<EOS>
Then

,
where

,
as

rolled
down

from
the

left

,
that

care
of
the
tall
mansion
which
lifted

.
<EOS>
Doubtless

park

,
but

.
<EOS>
He

which
was

<EOS>
the
level

lying

,

.
<EOS>
It
was
that

when

the
scythe
being

makes
us
cast
more

.
  
<EOS>
He
might

if

's

towards

;

.
<EOS>
Every

was

,
from
old
"
Feyther
Taft
"
in

,

,
but

down

.
<EOS>
Now

was

;

,

,

,

,

,
but

enough

.
<EOS>
But

on

Green
,

"
preacher
woman
"
 
they

"
what
war
a
-
goin
'
on
,
like
.
<EOS>
"
The
men
were
chiefly

the

of

's
shop
.
<EOS>
But
do
not
imagine
them
gathered
in
a
knot
.
<EOS>
Villagers
never
swarm
:
a
whisper
is
unknown
among
them
,
and
they
seem
almost
as
incapable
of
an
undertone
as
a
cow
or
a
stag
.
<EOS>
Your
true
rustic
turns
his
back
on
his
interlocutor
,
throwing
a
question
over
his
shoulder
as
if
he
meant
to
run
away
from
the
answer
,
and
walking
a
step
or
two
farther
off
when
the
interest
of
the
dialogue
culminates
.
<EOS>
So
the
group
in
the
vicinity
of
the
blacksmith
's
door
was
by
no
means
a
close
one
,
and
formed
no
screen
in
front
of
Chad
Cranage
,
the
blacksmith
himself
,
who
stood
with
his
black
brawny
arms
folded
,
leaning
against
the
door
-
post
,
and
occasionally
sending
forth
a
bellowing
laugh
at
his
own
jokes
,
giving
them
a
marked
preference
over
the
sarcasms
of
Wiry
Ben
,
who
had
renounced
the
pleasures
of
the
Holly
Bush
for
the
sake
of
seeing
life
under
a
new
form
.
<EOS>
But
both
styles
of
wit
were
treated
with
equal
contempt
by
Mr.
Joshua
Rann
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rann
's
leathern
apron
and
subdued
griminess
can
leave
no
one
in
any
doubt
that
he
is
the
village
shoemaker
;
<EOS>
the
thrusting
out
of
his
chin
and

and
the
twirling
of
his
thumbs
are
more
subtle
indications
,
intended
to
prepare
unwary

for
the
discovery
that
they
are
in
the
presence
of
the
parish

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Old
Joshway
,
"
as
he

irreverently

by

neighbours
,
is
in
a

;
but
he
has
not
yet

except
to
say
,
in

,

,
"
Sehon
,
King
of
the
Amorites
;
for
His
mercy
endureth
for
ever
;
and
Og
the
King
of
Basan
:
for
His
mercy
endureth
for
ever
"
 
a

which
may
seem
to
have
slight
bearing
on
the
present
occasion
,
but
,
as
with
every
other
anomaly
,
adequate

will
show

to
be
a
natural
sequence
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Rann
was
inwardly
maintaining
the
dignity
of
the
Church
in
the
face
of
this
scandalous
irruption
of
Methodism
,
and
as

was
bound
up
with
his
own
sonorous

of
the
responses
,
his
argument
naturally
suggested
a
quotation
from
the
psalm
he
had
read
the
last
Sunday
afternoon
.
  
<EOS>
The
stronger
curiosity
of
the
women
had
drawn
them
quite
to
the
edge
of
the
Green
,
where
they
could
examine
more

the
Quakerlike

and

of

female

.
<EOS>
Underneath

there
was
a

,
which
had

from

to

,
and

.
<EOS>
Some

were

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

"

war

.
<EOS>
"
Chad
's
Bess
was

,

,

"

.
  
<EOS>
Timothy

,

<EOS>
Several

's

,

,
as
Dinah

rather

and
in

under

-

.
<EOS>
While

was
near
Seth
's
tall
figure
,

,
but
when

had
mounted

cart
,

all

,
she
seemed
above
the
middle

of
woman
,
though

did
not

an

which

and

stuff

.
<EOS>
The
stranger
was
struck
with
surprise
as
he
saw
her
approach
and
mount
the
cart
 
surprise
,
not
so

at

of

,
as
at
the
total

of

-

.
<EOS>
He
had

to

and

of

;

had

that
her

would
be
mantled
with

,

.
<EOS>
He
knew
but
two
types
of
Methodist
 
the
ecstatic
and
the

.
<EOS>
But
Dinah
walked
as

as
if
she
were
going
to
market
,
and
seemed
as

:

no

,

,
which

,
"

,

"
;
no

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
held

in

,
but

down
lightly
crossed

,
as
she

and

.
<EOS>
There
was
no

in
the

;
they
seemed
rather
to
be

than

;
they
had
the
liquid

which
tells
that

is
full

,

.
<EOS>
She

with

,
and

screened
her
from

;
but

the

of
her

seemed
to

,

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
small

,
of

,
with

-
like

,

,

,

,

of
parting
between

.
<EOS>
The

was
drawn

back
behind

ears
,
and
covered
,

above

,
by

net

.
<EOS>
The

,

the

,
were
perfectly

and
firmly

;
the

,
though
no

,
were
long
and
abundant
 
<EOS>
nothing
was
left
blurred
or
unfinished
.
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
faces
that
make
one
think
of
white
flowers
with
light

of
colour
on

.
<EOS>
The

had
no

,
beyond
that
of

;
they

so

,

,

,
that
no

,
no
light

could
help
melting

.
<EOS>
Joshua
Rann
gave
a
long
cough
,
as
if
he
were
clearing
his
throat
in
order
to
come

new

with

;
Chad
Cranage
lifted

his
leather

-
cap
and
scratched

head
;
and
Wiry
Ben
wondered
how
Seth
had
the
pluck
to
think
of
courting
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
sweet
woman
,
"
the
stranger
said
to
himself
,
"
but
surely
nature
never
meant
her
for
a
preacher
.
"
  
<EOS>
Perhaps
he
was
one
of
those
who
think
that
nature
has
theatrical
properties
and
,
with
the
considerate
view
of
facilitating
art

,
"
makes

,
"
her
characters
,
so
that
there
may
be
no

about

.
<EOS>
But
Dinah
began
to
speak
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
friends
,
"
she
said
in
a
clear
but
not

voice
"
let
us
pray
for
a
blessing
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
closed
her
eyes
,
and
hanging
her
head
down
a
little
continued
in
the
same
moderate
tone
,
as
if
speaking
to
some
one
quite
near
her
:
"
Saviour
of
sinners
!
<EOS>
When
a
poor
woman
laden
with
sins
,
went

<EOS>
Hitherto

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
The

had

,

.

She

.
<EOS>

;

,
and

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
The

had

,

,
that

,

,

,
until

"
Lost
!
 
<EOS>
Sinners
!
<EOS>
"
when

.
<EOS>
She

before

,
and
the

by

that

.
<EOS>
Her
pale

became

;

,

when

half
-
gather

;

,

.
<EOS>
Her

,

.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
less
like
the
ordinary

of
the
Ranter
than

.
<EOS>
She
was

,
but

and

.
  
<EOS>
But

had

.
<EOS>
Her

less

,

,

their

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
At

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
After
the
Preaching
  
IN
less

,

.

Dinah
had

,

was

hands
that

,
and

,

.
<EOS>

of
absorption

or

own

an

is
most

.
<EOS>
Her
very

was
discouraging
:
it
had
that
quiet

that
asks
for
no
support
.
<EOS>
Seth
felt
this
dimly
;
he
said

<EOS>
He
was
but

-
and
-

,
and
had

is
to
love
 
to

.
<EOS>
Love

this

from

.
<EOS>
What
deep
and
worthy
love
is
so
,
whether
of
woman
or

,
or

or

.
<EOS>
Our

,
our

words
,
our
still

under

,

,

,

all

that

;

.
<EOS>
And
this

of

love
has

many

craftsmen
since

for

,

.
  
<EOS>
That

has

;

,

,

,

,

,

Presence
,

to

.
<EOS>
It

that

may

-

,

,

Methodism
in
many
fashionable
quarters
.
  
<EOS>
That
would
be
a
pity
;
for
I
can
not
pretend
that
Seth
and
Dinah
were
anything
else
than
Methodists
 
not
indeed
of
that
modern
type
which
reads
quarterly
reviews
and
attends
in
chapels
with
pillared
porticoes
,
but
of
a
very
old
-
fashioned
kind
.
<EOS>
They
believed
in
present
miracles
,
in
instantaneous
conversions
,
in
revelations
by
dreams
and
visions
;
they
drew
lots
,
and
sought
for
Divine
guidance
by
opening
the
Bible
at
hazard
;
having
a
literal
way
of
interpreting
the
Scriptures
,
which
is
not
at
all
sanctioned
by
approved
commentators
;
and
it
is
impossible
for
me
to
represent
their
diction
as
correct
,
or
their
instruction
as
liberal
.
<EOS>
Still
 
if
I
have
read
religious
history
aright
 
faith
,
hope
,
and
charity
have
not
always
been
found
in
a
direct
ratio
with
a
sensibility
to
the
three
concords
,
and
it
is
possible
 
thank
Heaven
!
 
<EOS>
to
have
very
erroneous
theories
and
very
sublime
feelings
.
<EOS>
The
raw
bacon
which
clumsy
Molly
spares
from
her
own
scanty
store
that
she
may
carry
it
to
her
neighbour
's
child
to
"
stop
the
fits
,
"
may
be
a
piteously
inefficacious
remedy
;
but
the
generous
stirring
of
neighbourly
kindness
that
prompted
the
deed
has
a
beneficent
radiation
that
is
not
lost
.
  
<EOS>
Considering
these
things
,
we
can
hardly
think
Dinah
and
Seth
beneath
our
sympathy
,
accustomed
as
we
may
be
to
weep
over
the
loftier
sorrows
of
heroines
in
satin
boots
and
crinoline
,
and
of
heroes
riding
fiery
horses
,
themselves
ridden
by
still
more
fiery
passions
.
  
<EOS>
Poor
Seth
!
<EOS>
He
was
never
on
horseback
in
his
life
except
once
,
when
he
was
a
little
lad
,
and
Mr.
Jonathan
Burge
took
him
up
behind
,
telling
him
to
"
hold
on
tight
"
;
and
instead
of
bursting
out
into
wild
accusing
apostrophes
to
God
and
destiny
,
he
is
resolving
,
as
he
now
walks
homewards
under
the
solemn
starlight
,
to
repress
his
sadness
,
to
be
less
bent
on
having
his
own
will
,
and
to
live
more
for
others
,
as
Dinah
does
.
    
<EOS>
Home
and
Its
Sorrows
  
<EOS>
A
GREEN
valley
with
a
brook
running
through
it
,
full
almost
to
overflowing
with
the
late
rains
,
<EOS>
overhung
by
low
stooping
willows
.
<EOS>
Across
this
brook
a
plank
is
thrown
,
and
over
this
plank
Adam
Bede
is
passing
with
his
undoubting
step
,
followed
close
by
Gyp
with
the
basket
;
evidently
making
his
way
to
the
thatched
house
,
with
a
stack
of
timber
by
the
side
of
it
,
about
twenty
yards
up
the
opposite
slope
.
  
<EOS>
The
door
of
the
house
is
open
,
and
an
elderly
woman
is
looking
out
;
but
she
is
not
placidly
contemplating
the
evening
sunshine
;
she
has
been
watching
with
dim
eyes
the
gradually
enlarging
speck
which
for
the
last
few
minutes
she
has
been
quite
sure
<EOS>
is
her
darling
son
Adam
.
<EOS>
Lisbeth
Bede
loves
her
son
with
the
love
of
a
woman
to
whom
her
first
-
born
has
come
late
in
life
.
<EOS>
She
is
an
anxious
,
spare
,
yet
vigorous
old
woman
,
clean
as
a

.
<EOS>
Her
grey
hair
is
turned

back
under
a
pure

with
a
black
band
<EOS>
round
it
<EOS>
;
her
broad

is
covered
with

,
and
below

you
see
a
sort

blue

,

,
<EOS>
from

a
considerable

linsey

.
<EOS>
For
Lisbeth
is
tall
,
and
in
other
points

there
is
a
strong

between
her
and
her
son
Adam
.
<EOS>
Her
dark

are
somewhat
dim
now
 
perhaps
from
too
much
crying
 
but
her
broadly
marked
eyebrows
are
still
black
,
her
teeth
are
sound
,
and
as

knitting
rapidly
and
unconsciously
with
her
work
-

hands
,
she
has
as
firmly
upright
an
attitude
as
when
she
is
carrying
a
pail

water
on
her
head
from
the
spring
.
<EOS>
There
is
the
same
type
of
frame
and
the
same
keen
activity
of
temperament
in
mother
and
son
,
but
it
was
not
from
her
that
Adam
got
his
well
-
filled
brow
and
his
expression
of
large
-
hearted
intelligence
.
  
<EOS>
Family
likeness
has
often
a
deep
sadness
in
it
.
<EOS>
Nature
,
that
great
tragic
dramatist
,
knits
us
together
by
bone
and
muscle
,
and
divides
us
by
the
subtler
web
of
our
brains
;
blends
yearning
and
repulsion
;
and
ties
us
by
our
heart

to
the

that
jar

.
<EOS>
We
hear
a
voice
with
the
very

our
own
uttering

;
we
see
eyes
 
ah
,
so
like
our
mother
's
!
 
<EOS>
averted
from

;
and

with
the

from
in

long

.
<EOS>
The
father
to

our
best
heritage
 
the

,

;

,

our

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Eh

.
<EOS>
I

"
Waggin

"
again

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
He

,
but

.

What

?
"

"
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
My

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

Why
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Thee't

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Lisbeth
did

,

wise
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But
one

the
lessons
a
woman
most

is
never

to
an

.
<EOS>
Lisbeth

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

.

well

,

.
<EOS>
Adam
noticed

's

,

<EOS>
We

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
Women

;

,

cake
,
and
then
we
'll
be
off
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
coffin
was
soon
propped
on
the
tall
shoulders
of
the
two
brothers
,
and
they
were
making
their
way
,
followed
close
by
Gyp
,
out
of
the
little
woodyard
into
the
lane
at
the
back
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
It
was
but
about
a
mile
and
a
half
to
Broxton
over
the
opposite
slope
,
and
their
road
wound
very
pleasantly
along
lanes
and
across
fields
,
where
the
pale
woodbines
and
the
dog
-
roses
were
scenting
the
hedgerows
,
and
the
birds
were
twittering
and
trilling
in
the
tall
leafy
boughs
of
oak
and
elm
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
strangely
mingled
picture
 
the
fresh
youth
of
the
summer
morning
,
with
its
Edenlike
peace
and
loveliness
,
the
stalwart
strength
of
the
two
brothers
in
their
rusty
working
clothes
,
and
the
long
coffin
on
their
shoulders
.
<EOS>
They
paused
for
the
last
time
before
a
small
farmhouse
outside
the
village
of
Broxton
.
<EOS>
By
six
o'clock
the
task
was
done
,
the
coffin
nailed
down
,
and
Adam
and
Seth
were
on
their
way
home
.
<EOS>
They
chose
a
shorter
way
homewards
,
which
would
take
them
across
the
fields
and
the
brook
in
front
of
the
house
.
<EOS>
Adam
had
not
mentioned
to
Seth
what
had
happened
in
the
night
,
but
he
still
retained
sufficient
impression
from
it
himself
to
say
,
"
Seth
,
lad
,
if

is

by

,
I
think
it
'll
be
as
well
for
thee
to
go
over
to
Treddles'on
and
look
after
him
,
and
thee
canst
get
me
the
brass
wire
I
want
.
<EOS>
Never
mind
about
losing
an
hour
at
thy
work
;
we
can
make
that
up
.
<EOS>
What
dost
say
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm
willing
,
"
said

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
see
what
clouds
have
gathered
since

.
<EOS>
I
'm
thinking
we

have
more

.
<EOS>
It

a
sore

for
th
'

.
<EOS>
The

's
fine

:
another

's
rain
'
ud
cover
the

,
and
we

go
round

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
were

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
what
's
that

against

willow
?
"
<EOS>
continued

,

.
<EOS>
Adam
's
heart
rose
to
his
mouth
:
the
vague

about
his
father
was
changed
into

.
<EOS>
He

,
who

to

;
and
in
two

he

at
the

.
  
<EOS>
This
was
what
the
omen
meant
,
then
!
<EOS>
And
the
grey

haired
father
,

had
thought

a

,
as

live
to

thorn

side
was
perhaps

then
struggling
with
that

!
<EOS>
This

's

,
before

to

and

.
<EOS>
Seth
was
already
by

,

,
and
when

,

in

and

,

need

forgetting

but
that

.
<EOS>
Adam
was
the
first
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
run
to

,
"
he

,
in

.
<EOS>
"
I
'll
be

to
thee
in

.
"
  
<EOS>
Poor
Lisbeth
was
busy

her
sons
'

,
and
their

was
already

.
<EOS>
Her

always

the

,
but

than

.
  
<EOS>
"
The
lads
'
ull
be
fine
an
'
hungry
<EOS>
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
It

Brox'on
,
an
'

o'er

wi

.
<EOS>
Eh
!
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
Howiver

.
<EOS>

.

.

that

o

.
<EOS>
Eh
,

mon
,
he
takes

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

"

.

,

,
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
Father
's
tumbled

.
<EOS>
Belike

.
<EOS>
Seth

.
<EOS>
Get

the

.
"
  
<EOS>
In

was

but

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

in

.
<EOS>
The
wide
-

were

,
like

,
and

before

.
<EOS>
Seth
's

was
awe
and

at
this

away
of
his
father
's

;
but
Adam
's

rushed
back

relenting
and

.
<EOS>
When
death
,
the
great
Reconciler
,
has
come
,
it
is
never
our
tenderness
that
we
repent
of
,
but
our
severity
.
    
<EOS>
The
Rector
  
<EOS>
BEFORE
twelve
o'clock
there
had
been
some
heavy
storms
of
rain
,
and
the
water
lay
in
deep
gutters
on
the
sides
of
the
gravel
walks
in
the
garden
of
Broxton
Parsonage
;
the
great
Provence
roses
had
been
cruelly
tossed
by
the
wind
and
beaten
by
the
rain
,
and
all
the
delicate
-
stemmed
border
flowers
had
been
dashed
down
and
stained
with
the
wet
soil
.
<EOS>
A
melancholy
morning
 
because
it
was
nearly
time
hay
-
harvest
should
begin
,
and
instead
of
that
the
meadows
were
likely
to
be
flooded
.
  
<EOS>
But
people
who
have
pleasant
homes
get
indoor
enjoyments
that
they
would
never
think
of
but
for
the
rain
.
<EOS>
If
it
had
not
been
a
wet
morning
,
Mr.
Irwine
would
not
have
been
in
the
dining
-
room
playing
at
chess
with
his
mother
,
and
he
loves
both
his
mother
and
chess
quite
well
enough
to
pass
some
cloudy
hours
very
easily
by
their
help
.
<EOS>
Let
me
take
you
into
that
dining
-
room
and
show
you
the
Rev.
Adolphus
Irwine
,
Rector
of
Broxton
,
Vicar
of
Hayslope
,
and
Vicar
of
Blythe
,
a
pluralist
at
whom
the
severest
Church
reformer
would
have
found
it
difficult
to
look
sour
.
<EOS>
We
will
enter
very
softly
and
stand
still
in
the
open
doorway
,
without
awaking
the
glossy
-
brown
setter
who
is
stretched
across
the
hearth
,
with
her
two
puppies
beside
her
;
or
the
pug
,
who
is
dozing
,
with
his
black
muzzle
aloft
,
like
a
sleepy
president
.
  
<EOS>
The
room
is
a
large
and
lofty
one
,
with
an
ample
mullioned
oriel
window
at
one
end
;
the
walls
,
you
see
,
are
new
,
and
not
yet
painted
;
but
the
furniture
,
though
originally
of
an
expensive
sort
,
is
old
and
scanty
,
and
there
is
no
drapery
about
the
window
.
<EOS>
The
crimson
cloth
over
the
large
dining
-
table
is
very
threadbare
,
though
it
contrasts
pleasantly
enough
with
the
dead
hue
of
the
plaster
on
the
walls
;
but
on
this
cloth
there
is
a
massive
silver
waiter
with
a
decanter
of
water
on
it
,
of
the
same
pattern
as
two
larger
ones
that
are
propped
up
on
the
sideboard
with
a
coat
of
arms
conspicuous
in
their
centre
.
<EOS>
You
suspect
at
once
that
the
inhabitants
of
this
room
have
inherited
more
blood
than
wealth
,
and
would
not
be
surprised
to
find
that
Mr.
Irwine
had
a
finely
cut
nostril
and
upper
lip
;
but
at
present
we
can
only
see
that
he
has
a
broad
flat
back
and
an
abundance
of
powdered
hair
,
all
thrown
backward
and
tied
behind
with
a
black
ribbon
 
a
bit
of
conservatism
in
costume
which
tells
you
that
he
is
not
a
young
man
.
<EOS>
He
will
perhaps
turn
round
by
and
by
,
and
in
the
meantime
we
can
look
at
that
stately
old
lady
,
his
mother
,
a
beautiful
aged
brunette
,
whose
rich
-
toned
complexion
is
well
set
off
by
the
complex
wrappings
of
pure
white
cambric
and
lace
about
her
head
and
neck
.
<EOS>
She
is
as
erect
in
her
comely
embonpoint
as
a
statue
of
Ceres
;
and
her
dark
face
,
with
its
delicate
aquiline
nose
,
firm
proud
mouth
,
and
small
,
intense
,
black
eye
,
is
so
keen
and
sarcastic
in
its
expression
that
you
instinctively
substitute
a
pack
of
cards
for
the
chess
-
men
and
imagine
her
telling
your
fortune
.
<EOS>
The
small
brown
hand
with
which
she
is
lifting
her
queen
is
laden
with
pearls
,
diamonds
,
and
turquoises
;
and
a
large
black
veil
is
very
carefully
adjusted
over
the
crown
of
her
cap
,
and
falls
in
sharp
contrast
on
the
white
folds
about
her
neck
.
<EOS>
It
must
take
a
long
time
to
dress
that
old
lady
in
the
morning
!
<EOS>
But
it
seems
a
law
of
nature
that
she
should
be
dressed
so
:
she
is
clearly
one
of
those
children
of
royalty
who
have
never
doubted
their
right
divine
and
never
met
with
any
one
so
absurd
as
to
question
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
There
,
Dauphin
,
tell
me
what
that
is
!
"
<EOS>
says
this
magnificent
old
lady
,
as
she
deposits
her
queen
very
quietly
and
folds
her
arms
.
<EOS>
"
I
should
be
sorry
to
utter
a
word
disagreeable
to
your
feelings
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
you
witch
-
mother
,
you

!
<EOS>
How
is

Christian
man
to

?
<EOS>
I

sprinkled

.
<EOS>
You
've
not
won
that
game
by
fair

,
now
,
so
do
n't
pretend

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
that
's
what
the
beaten
have
always

.
<EOS>
But

,

's
the

falling
on
the
board
,
to
show

more

what
a
foolish
move
you
made
with
that

.
<EOS>
Come
,

give

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
Mother
,
I
shall

,
now

's

.
<EOS>
We

and
plash

a

,
mus'n't

,
Juno
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This
was
addressed
to
the
brown
setter
,
who
had
jumped

at
the
sound

and
laid
her

in

on

's

.
<EOS>
"
But
I
must
go
upstairs

and

Anne
.
<EOS>
I
was
called
away
to
Tholer
's
funeral
just
when
I
was
going
before
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
of
no
use
,
child
;
she
ca
n't
speak
to
you
.
<EOS>
Kate
says
she
has
one
of
her
worst
headaches
this
morning
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
she
likes
me
to
go
and
see
her
just
the
same
;
she
's
never
too
ill
to
care
about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If
you
know
how
much
of
human
speech
is
mere
purposeless
impulse
or
habit
,
you
will
not
wonder
when
I
tell
you
that
this
identical
objection
had
been
made
,
and
had

the
same
kind

answer
,
many
hundred
times
in
the
course
of
the
fifteen

that
Mr.
Irwine
's
sister
Anne
had
been
an
invalid
.
<EOS>
Splendid
old
ladies
,
who
take
a
long
time
to
dress
in
the
morning
,
have
often
slight
sympathy
with
sickly
daughters
.
  
<EOS>
But
while
Mr.
Irwine
was
still
seated
,
leaning
back
in
his
chair
and

's

,

came

the

and
said
,
"
If
you
please
,
sir
,
Joshua
Rann
wishes
to

,
if
you

at

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
him
be
shown
in
here
,
"
said
Mrs.
Irwine
,
taking
up
her
knitting
.
<EOS>
"
I
always
like
to
hear
what
Mr.
Rann
has
got
to
say
.
<EOS>
His
shoes
will
be
dirty
,
but
see
that
he
wipes
them
Carroll
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
two
minutes
Mr.
Rann
appeared
at
the
door
with
very
deferential
bows
,
which
,
however
,
were
far
from
conciliating
Pug
,
who
gave
a
sharp

and
ran
across
the
room
to
reconnoitre
the
stranger
's
legs
;
while
the
two
puppies
,
regarding
Mr.
Rann
's
prominent
calf
and
ribbed
worsted
stockings
from
a
more
sensuous
point
of
view
,
plunged
and
growled
over
them
in
great

.
<EOS>

,

Irwine

,
"

reformers

abuses
beyond
the
threshold
of
their

.
  
<EOS>
But

Irwine

portly

<EOS>

They

<EOS>
The
Hall

EVIDENTLY
that

,

long

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>

!
<EOS>
For

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
Yes
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
It

once

a

,
whose

,
probably

.
<EOS>
It

Hall

.
<EOS>
Like

,

<EOS>
Plenty

,

<EOS>
But

<EOS>
There

For

<EOS>
The
Dairy
  
<EOS>
THE
dairy
was
certainly
worth
looking
at
:
it
was
a
scene
to
sicken
for
with
a
sort
of

in
hot

<EOS>
such

,
such

,
such
fresh

of
new
-
pressed

,
of
firm

,
of

perpetually
bathed
in

;
such
soft

of
red

and

,
brown
wood
and

,
grey

and
rich

-
red

.
<EOS>
But
one
gets
only

confused
notion
of
these
details
when
they
surround
a
distractingly
pretty
girl
of

,
standing
on
little
pattens
and
rounding
her
dimpled
arm
to
lift
a
pound
of
butter
out
of
the
scale
.
  
<EOS>
Hetty
blushed

deep
rose
-
colour
when

Donnithorne
entered
the
dairy
and

to

;
but

,
for

,
and

,

;

for

so
long
as
the

were

all

,
and
a
large
quantity
but
inferior
quality
of

by
the

,
which
had
been
bought
on

,
together

other

which
must

a
young

who
would

,
Hetty
tossed

patted
her
pound
of

quite
a
self
-
possessed
,
coquettish
air
,
slyly
conscious
that
no
turn
of
her
head
was
lost
.
  
<EOS>
There
are
various
orders
of
beauty
,
causing
men
to
make
fools
of
themselves
in
various
styles
,
from
the
desperate
to
the
sheepish
;
but
there
is
one
order
of
beauty
which
seems
made
to
turn
the
heads
not
only
of
men
,
but
of
all
intelligent
mammals
,
even
of
women
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
beauty
like
that
of
kittens
,
or
very
small
<EOS>
downy
ducks
making
gentle
rippling
noises
with
their
soft
bills
,
or
babies
just
beginning
to
toddle
and
to
engage
in
conscious
mischief
 
a
beauty
with
which
you
can
never
be
angry
,
but
that
you
feel
ready
to
crush
for
inability
to
comprehend
the
state
of
mind
into
which
it
throws
you
.
<EOS>
Hetty
Sorrel
's
was
that
sort
of
beauty
.
<EOS>
Her
aunt
,
Mrs.
Poyser
,
who
professed

despise

and
intended

,

at
Hetty
's
charms
by
the
sly
,
fascinated
in

herself
;

after

such

scolding
as

from
her

do
well
by
her
husband
's
niece
 
who
had

own

,
poor

!
 
<EOS>
she

"
the

.
"
  
<EOS>
It

is

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Dinah
Visits
<EOS>
Lisbeth
  
<EOS>
AT
five
o'clock
<EOS>
Lisbeth
came
downstairs
with
a
large
key
in
her
hand
:
it
was
the
key
of
the
chamber
where
her
husband
lay
dead
.
<EOS>
Throughout

day
,
except
in
her

,
she
had
been
in

,
performing

initial

to
her
dead
with

that
belong
to

rites
.
<EOS>
She
had
brought
out
her

,
which

had
for

years
kept
in

for
this

.
<EOS>
It
seemed
but
yesterday
 
that
time
so

ago
,

had

Thias
where
this
linen
lay
,

<EOS>

.

,

he

"
  
Dinah

.
<EOS>
This

,
through

still

.
<EOS>
From

had

among

,

,
and
had

the

of

and

.
<EOS>
As

,
"
she

;
but

when

.
"
<EOS>
And

?
<EOS>
After

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
And

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
In

<EOS>
IT

but

-

<EOS>

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

;

,

Seth
,

.
<EOS>
Seth
,

,

only

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

ordinary

;

.
  
<EOS>
But
Adam
had

,

of

,

and
subdue

by

.
<EOS>
The

;

was

,
and
he

.
  
<EOS>
"
There
's
nothing
<EOS>
but
what
's

,
"

;
"
the
natur
o
'

,

's

.
<EOS>
The
square
o
'
four

,

your

,
is

;
and

o
'

,

<EOS>
o
'

.
<EOS>
"

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
He
had
just

into
the

stairs
 
certainly

's
.
<EOS>
He

had
come
in
,
in

,
and
now

whose
step

.
<EOS>
A

came
,
and

.
<EOS>
As

could
be
Hetty
!
<EOS>
She
was

.
<EOS>
And

else
.
<EOS>
He
stood

a

he
had
taken

of
,
listening

which
his
imagination
interpreted
for
him
so

that
the
keen
strong
face
became

.
<EOS>
The
light
footstep
moved
about

kitchen
,
followed
by
the
sound
of
the
sweeping
brush
,
hardly
making
so
much

as
the
lightest

that

along

;
and
Adam
's

saw
a
dimpled

,

dark

this

,
and
a
rounded
figure
just

little
to

.
<EOS>
A
very
foolish
thought
 
it
could
not
be
Hetty
;
but

WHO

,
for
his

belief
while

.
<EOS>
He
loosed
the
plank
and
went
to
the
kitchen
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
do
you
do
,
Adam
Bede
?
"
said
Dinah
,
in
her

treble
,
pausing
from

and

.
<EOS>
"
I
trust
you
feel
rested
and
strengthened
again
to
bear
the
burden
and
heat

the
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
like
dreaming
of
the
sunshine
and
awaking
in
the
moonlight
.
<EOS>
Adam
had
seen
Dinah
several
times
,
but
always
at
the
Hall
Farm
,
where
he
was
not

conscious
of
any
woman
's
presence
except
Hetty
's
,
and
he
had
only
in
the
last
day
or
two
begun

that
Seth
was
in

her
,
so
that

not

for
his

's

.
<EOS>
But
now
her
slim

,
her

,
and
her
pale

face
impressed
him
with
all
the
force
that
belongs
to

a

.
<EOS>
For
the
first
moment
or
two
he
made
no
answer
,
but
looked
at
her
with
the
concentrated
,

which
a
man
gives
to
an
object
in
which
he
has
suddenly
begun
to
be
interested
.
<EOS>
Dinah
,
for
the
first
time
in
her
life
,
felt
a
painful
self
-
consciousness
;
there
was
something
in
the
dark
penetrating
glance
of
this
strong
man
so
different
from
the
mildness
and
timidity
of
his
brother
Seth
.
<EOS>
A
faint
blush
came
,
which
deepened
as
she
wondered
at
it
.
<EOS>
This
blush
recalled
Adam
from
his
forgetfulness
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
quite
taken
by
surprise
;
it
was
very
good
of
you
to
come
and
see
my
mother
in

<EOS>
The

in

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

a

<EOS>

<EOS>

Arthur

<EOS>
Ah
!

<EOS>

<EOS>

the

has
been

.
<EOS>
Not

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Those

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

:

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
It

.

which
love
gives
to
the
quickest

,

,

and

.

"

,

"

.

.

<EOS>
Dinah
,

,

,

.
<EOS>

:

<EOS>
she
's

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"

,

.

,

,

.

"

,

;

,
"

,

"
<EOS>

i

.

,

.

<EOS>
The

,

old

,
by

,

-

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

,

,

;

.

"

,

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
You

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
Good

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
    
<EOS>
The
Two
Bed
-
Chambers
  
HETTY
and
Dinah
both
slept
in
the
second
story
,
in
rooms
adjoining
each
other
,
meagrely
furnished
rooms
,
with
no
blinds
to
shut
out
the
light
,
which
was
now
beginning
to
gather
new
strength
from
the
rising
of
the
moon
 
more
than
enough
strength
to
enable
Hetty
to
move
about
and
undress
with
perfect
comfort
.
<EOS>
She
could
see
quite
well
the
pegs
in
the
old
painted
linen
-
press
on
which
she
hung
her
hat
and
gown
;
she
could
see
the
head
of
every
pin
on
her
red
cloth
pin
-
cushion
;
she
could
see
a
reflection
of
herself
in
the
old
-
fashioned
looking
-
glass
,
quite
as
distinct
as
was
needful
,
considering
that
she
had
only
to
brush
her
hair
and
put
on
her
night
-
cap
.
<EOS>
A
queer
old
looking
-
glass
!
<EOS>
Hetty
got
into
an
ill
temper
with
it
almost
every
time
she
dressed
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
considered
a
handsome
glass
in
its
day
,
and
had
probably
been
bought
into
the
Poyser
family
a
quarter
of
a
century
before
,
at
a
sale
of
genteel
household
furniture
.
<EOS>
Even
now
an
auctioneer
could
say
something
for
it
:
it
had
a
great
deal
of
tarnished
gilding
about
it
;
it
had
a
firm
mahogany
base
,
well
supplied
with
drawers
,
which
opened
with
a
decided
jerk
and
sent
the
contents
leaping
out
from
the
farthest
corners
,
without
giving
you
the
trouble
of
reaching
them
;
above
all
,
it
had
a
brass
candle
-
socket
on
each
side
,
which
would
give
it
an
aristocratic
air
to
the
very
last
.
<EOS>
But
Hetty
objected
to
it
because
it
had
numerous
dim
blotches
sprinkled
over
the
mirror
,
which
no
rubbing
would
remove
,
and
because
,
instead
of
swinging
backwards
and
forwards
,
it
was
fixed
in
an
upright
position
,
so
that
she
could
only
get
one
good
view
of
her
head
and
neck
,
and
that
was
to
be
had
only
by
sitting
down
on
a
low
chair
before
her
dressing
-
table
.
<EOS>
And
the
dressing
-
table
was
no
dressing
-
table
at
all
,
but
a
small
old
chest
of
drawers
,
the
most
awkward
thing
in
the
world
to
sit
down
before
,
for
<EOS>
the
big
brass
handles
quite
hurt
her
knees
,
and
she
could
n't
get
near
the
glass
at
all
comfortably
.
<EOS>
But
devout
worshippers
never
allow
inconveniences
to
prevent
them
from
performing
their
religious
rites
,
and
Hetty
this
evening
was
more
bent
on
her
peculiar
form
of
worship
than
usual
.
  
<EOS>
Having
taken
off
her
gown
and
white
kerchief
,
she
drew
a
key
from
the
large
pocket
that
hung
outside
her
petticoat
,
and
,
unlocking
one
of
the
lower
drawers
in
the
chest
,
reached
from
it
two
short
bits
of
wax
candle
 
secretly
bought
at
Treddleston
 
and
stuck
them
in
the
two
brass
sockets
.
<EOS>
Then
she
drew
forth
a
bundle
of
matches
and
lighted
the
candles
;
and
last
of
all
,
a
small
red
-
framed
shilling
looking
-
glass
,
without
blotches
.
<EOS>
It
was
into
this
small
glass
that
she
chose
to
look
first
after
seating
herself
.
<EOS>
She
looked
into
it
,
smiling
and
turning
her
head
on
one
side
,
for
a
minute
,
then
laid
it
down
and
took
out
her
brush
and
comb
from
an
upper
drawer
.
<EOS>
She
was
going
to
let
down
her
hair
,
and
make
herself
look
like
that
picture
of
a
lady
in
Miss
Lydia
Donnithorne
's
dressing
-
room
.
<EOS>
It
was
soon
done
,
and
the
dark
hyacinthine
curves
fell
on
her
neck
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
heavy
,
massive
,
merely
rippling
hair
,
but
soft
and
silken
,
running
at
every
opportunity
into
delicate
rings
.
<EOS>
But
she
pushed
it
all
backward
to
look
like
the
picture
,
and
form
a
dark
curtain
,
throwing
into
relief
her
round
white
neck
.
<EOS>
Then
she
put
down
her
brush
and
comb
and
looked
at
herself
,
folding
her
arms
before
her
,
still
like
the
picture
.
<EOS>
Even
the
old
mottled
glass
could
n't
help
sending
back
a
lovely
image
,
none
the
less
lovely
because
Hetty
's
stays
were
not
of
white
satin
 
<EOS>
such
as
I
feel
sure
heroines
must
generally
wear
 
<EOS>
but
of
a
dark
greenish
cotton
texture
.
  
<EOS>
Oh
yes
!
<EOS>
She
was
very
pretty
.
<EOS>
Captain
Donnithorne
thought
so
.
<EOS>
Prettier
than
anybody
about
Hayslope
 
prettier
than
any
of
the
ladies
she
had
ever
seen
visiting
at
the
Chase
 
<EOS>
indeed
it
seemed
fine
ladies
were
rather
old
and
ugly
 
and
prettier
than
Miss
Bacon
,
the
miller
's
daughter
,
who
was
called
the
beauty
of
Treddleston
.
<EOS>
And
Hetty
looked
at
herself
to
-
night
with
quite
a
different
sensation
from
what
she
had
ever
felt
before
;
there
was
an
invisible
spectator
whose
eye
rested
on
her
like
morning
on
the
flowers
.
<EOS>
His
soft
voice
was
saying
over
and
over
again
those
pretty
things
she
had
heard
in
the
wood
;
his
arm
was
round
her
,
and
the
delicate
rose
-
scent
of
his
hair
was
with
her
still
.
<EOS>
The
vainest
woman
is
never
thoroughly
conscious
of
her
own
beauty
till
she
is
loved
by
the
man
who
sets
her
own
passion
vibrating
in
return
.
  
<EOS>
But
Hetty
seemed
to
have
made
up
her
mind
that
something
was
wanting
,
for
she
got
up

"

"

<EOS>
trouble

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

the

vocation
of
the
novelist
to
represent
things
as
they
never
have
been
and
never
will
be
.
<EOS>
Then
,
of
course
,
I
might
refashion
life
and
character
entirely
after
my
own
liking
;
I
might
select
the
most
unexceptionable
type
of
clergyman
and
put
my
own
admirable
opinions
into
his
mouth
on
all
occasions
.
<EOS>
But
it
happens
,
on
the
contrary
,
that
my
strongest
effort
is
to
avoid
any
such
arbitrary
picture
,
and
to
give
a
faithful
account
of
men
and
things
as
they
have
mirrored
themselves
in
my
mind
.
<EOS>
The
mirror
is
doubtless
defective
,
the
outlines
will
sometimes
be
disturbed
,
the
reflection
faint
or
confused
;
but
I
feel
as
much
bound
to
tell
you
as
precisely
as
I
can
what
that
reflection
is
,
as
if
I
were
in
the
witness
-
box
,
narrating
my
experience
on
oath
.
  
<EOS>
Sixty
years
ago
 
it
is
a
long
time
,
so
<EOS>
no
wonder
things
have
changed
 
all
clergymen
were
not
zealous
;
indeed
,
there
is
reason
to
believe
that
the
number
of
zealous
clergymen
was
small
,
and
it
is
probable
that
if
one
among
the
small
minority
had
owned
the
livings
of
Broxton
and
Hayslope
in
the
year
1799
,
you
would
have
liked
him
no
better
than
you
like
Mr.
Irwine
.
<EOS>
Ten
to
one
,
you
would
have
thought
him
a
tasteless
,
indiscreet
,
methodistical
man
.
<EOS>
It
is
so
very
rarely
that
facts
hit
that
nice
medium
required
by
our
own
enlightened
opinions
and
refined

!
<EOS>
Perhaps
you
will
say
,
"
Do
improve
the
facts
a
little
,
then
;
make
them
more
accordant
with
those
correct
views
which
it
is
our
privilege
to
possess
.
<EOS>
The
world
is
not
just
what
we
like
;
do
touch
it
up
with
a
tasteful
pencil
,
and
make
believe
it
is
not
quite
such
a
mixed
entangled
affair
.
<EOS>
Let
all
people
who
hold
unexceptionable
opinions
act
unexceptionably
.
<EOS>
Let
your
most
faulty
characters
always
be
on
the
wrong
side
,
and
your
virtuous
ones
on
the
right
.
<EOS>
Then
we
shall
see
at
a
glance
whom
we
are
to
condemn
and
whom
we
are
to
approve
.
<EOS>
Then
we
shall
be
able
to
admire
,
without
the
slightest
disturbance
of
our
prepossessions
:
we
shall
hate
and
despise
with
that
true
ruminant
relish
which
belongs
to
undoubting
confidence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
,
my
good
friend
,
what
will
you
do
then
with
your
fellow
-
parishioner
who
opposes
your
husband
in

vestry
?
<EOS>
With
your
newly
appointed
vicar
,
whose
style

you
find

below

of

?
<EOS>
With
the
honest

who

one

?
<EOS>
With
your

,
Mrs.
Green
,

was

,
but

?
<EOS>
Nay
,

your
excellent

,
who
has
other

of
not

?
<EOS>
These
fellow
-
mortals
,
every

,
must
be
accepted
as

are
:
you
can
neither

,

,

;
and
it

people
 
amongst

your

is
passed
 
that

should

,

,
and
love
<EOS>
:
it
is
these
more

ugly
,
stupid
,
inconsistent
people
whose

of
goodness
you
should
be
able
to
admire
 
for

you
should
cherish
all

,

.
<EOS>
And
I
would
not
,
even

,
be
the
clever

who
could
create

so

,

,

common

fields
 
on
the
real
breathing
men

,
who
can

;

by

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
So
I
am
content
to
tell
my
simple
story
,
without
trying
to
make
things
seem
better
than
they
were
;
dreading
nothing
,
indeed
,
but
falsity
,
which
,
in

one
's
best

,
there

to

.
<EOS>
Falsehood
is
so
easy
,
truth
so
difficult
.
<EOS>
The
pencil
is
conscious
of
a
delightful
facility
in
drawing
a
griffin
 
the
longer
the
claws
,
and
the
larger
the
wings
,
the
better
;
but
that
marvellous
facility
which
we
mistook
for
genius
is
apt
to

us
when
we
want
to
draw
a
real

lion
.
<EOS>
Examine
your
words
well
,
and
you
will
find
that
even
when
you
have
no

to
be
false
,
it
is
a
very
hard

to
say
the
exact

,
even
about
your
own
immediate
feelings
 
much

than
to

something
fine
about
them
which
is
NOT

.
  
<EOS>
It
is
for
this
rare
,
precious

of

that
I
delight

many

,
which
lofty

.
<EOS>
I
find

in
these

of
a

,
which
has

so

,

.
<EOS>
I
turn
,
without

,

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
or

turn

,

,

,

,
<EOS>
but
with
an
expression

.
<EOS>
"
Foh
!
"

,
"
what

!
<EOS>

<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>
What

!
"
  
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
I

"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

;

,

their

flattering
,
but

are

.
<EOS>
I
have

many
an

,

could

never

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

.
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
Thank
God
;
human
feeling
is
like

rivers
that
bless

earth
:
it
does
not

for
beauty
 
<EOS>
it
flows
with

and

with

.
  
<EOS>
All

and

to

form
!
<EOS>
Let

cultivate

to
the
utmost
in

,

,

in

.
<EOS>
But

that

too
,
which
lies
in
no

of
proportion
,
but
in

deep

.
<EOS>
Paint
us
an

,
if
you

,
with
a

,

by

;

,

;

Art
those

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
In
this

there
are
so
many

these
common

,

no

!
<EOS>
It

,
else

.
<EOS>
Therefore
,

Art

;

of

life
to

things
 
men

in

,

.
<EOS>
There

few

;

;

.
<EOS>
I
ca

:

fellow

men
,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Neither

half

,

.
<EOS>
It

in

,

.
  
<EOS>
And

,

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
They

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
But
,
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
a

And
now
the
little
procession
set
off
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Poyser
was
in
his
Sunday

of
drab
,
with
a
red
-
and
-

and
a

,

like

from
that

where

was
situated
;
a

of
a
yellow

;
and
excellent
grey

,
knitted
by
Mrs.
Poyser
's
own
hand
,
setting
off
the
proportions
of
his
leg
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Poyser
had
no
reason
to
be
ashamed
of
his
leg
,
and
suspected
that
the
growing
abuse
of
top
-

and

tending
to
disguise

nether

had
their

in
a

of

.
<EOS>
Still
less

to
be

of
his
round

,
which
was
good

itself
as

,
"
Come
,
Hetty
 
come
,
little

!
"
<EOS>
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
The
"

uns
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
Hetty
walked
between

,
and
behind

patient

,
whose

to

Totty

yard
and

wet

on

;
for
Totty
,
having

from

had
insisted

to
church
to
-
day
,
and

wearing

red

.
<EOS>
And
there
were
many
wet
places
for

to
be
carried
over
this

,
for
there
had

heavy

in

morning
,
though
now

had
rolled
off
and

in

.
  
<EOS>
You
might

Sunday
if

.
<EOS>
The
cocks
and

seemed
to
know
it
,
and

subdued

;
the
very

dog

less

,

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
It
was

Alick

"
<EOS>
Church
!
<EOS>
Nay
 
I'n

"

<EOS>
I

most
striking
attitude
 
that

to

,

<EOS>
:

<EOS>
Ah

<EOS>

Molly

"

,

:

.
<EOS>
Hetty

;

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Hetty

:

,

;

rather

<EOS>
people
should
know

.

What

,

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
But

's

;

,
as

of
our
entire
past
and
our
imagined
future
blends
itself
with
all

of
keen

.
<EOS>
And
to
Adam
the
church
service
was
the
best
channel
he
could

for
his
mingled

,

,

;
its

,

,
seemed

as
no
other

done
;
as
,
to
those
early

who
had

from

,

-

and

than

of

.
<EOS>
The
secret
of
our
emotions
never

in

bare

,
but
in
its
subtle
relations
to
our

past
:
no
wonder

secret
escapes
the
unsympathizing
observer
,
who
might

to

odours
.
  
<EOS>
But
there
was

.
  
<EOS>

,

:

.

,

.
<EOS>
"

So

where

Hall

all

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

;

need

have
gone
 
<EOS>
he

.
<EOS>
She

that

if

;

,

,
and

with
that

which
one
may

the
"
growing
pain
"
of
passion
.
    
<EOS>
Adam
on
a
Working
Day
  
<EOS>
NOTWITHSTANDING
Mr.
Craig
's
prophecy
,
the
dark
-
blue
cloud
dispersed
itself
without
having
produced
the
threatened
consequences
.
<EOS>
"
The
weather
"
 
as
he
observed
the
next
morning
 
<EOS>
"
the
weather
,
you
see
,
's
a
ticklish
thing
,
an
'
a
fool
'
ull
hit
on't
sometimes
when
a
wise
man
misses
;
that
's
why
the
almanecks
get
so
much
credit
.
<EOS>
It
's
<EOS>
one
o
'
them
chancy
things
as
fools
thrive
on
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This
unreasonable
behaviour
of
the
weather
,
however
,
could
displease
no
one
else
in
Hayslope
besides
Mr.
Craig
.
<EOS>
All
hands
were
to
be
out
in
the
meadows
this
morning
as
soon
as
the
dew
had
risen
;
the
wives
and
daughters
did
double
work
in
every
farmhouse
,
that
the
maids
might
give
their
help
in
tossing
the
hay
;
and
when
Adam
was
marching
along
the
lanes
,
with
his
basket
of
tools
over
his
shoulder
,
he
caught
the
sound
of
jocose
talk
and
ringing
laughter
from
behind
the
hedges
.
<EOS>
The
jocose
talk
of
hay
-
makers
is
best
at
a
distance
;
like
those
clumsy
bells
round
the
cows
'
necks
,
it
has
rather
a
coarse
sound
when
it
comes
close
,
and
may
even
grate
on
your
ears
painfully
;
but
heard
from
far
off
,
it
mingles
very
prettily
with
the
other
joyous
sounds
of
nature
.
<EOS>
Men
's
muscles
move
better
when
their
souls
are
making
merry
music
,
though
their
merriment
is
of
a
poor
blundering
sort
,
not
at
all
like
the
merriment
of
birds
.
  
<EOS>
And
perhaps
there
is
no
time
in
a
summer
's
day
more
cheering
than
when
the
warmth
of
the
sun
is
just
beginning
to
triumph
over
the
freshness
of
the
morning
 
<EOS>
when
there
is
just
a
lingering
hint
of
early
coolness
to
keep
off
languor
under
the
delicious
influence
of
warmth
.
<EOS>
The
reason
Adam
was
walking
along
the
lanes
at
this
time
was
because
his
work
for
the
rest
of
the
day
lay
at
a
country
-
house
about
three
miles
off
,
which
was
being
put
in
repair
for
the
son
of
a
neighbouring
squire
;
and
he
had
been
busy
since
early
morning
with
the
packing
of
panels
,
doors
,
and
chimney
-
pieces
,
in
a
waggon
which
was
now
gone
on
before
him
,
while
Jonathan
Burge
himself
had
ridden
to
the
spot
on
horseback
,
to
await
its
arrival
and
direct
the
workmen
.
  
<EOS>
This
little
walk
was
a
rest
to
Adam
,
and
he
was
unconsciously
under
the
charm
of
the
moment
.
<EOS>
It
was
summer
morning
in
his
heart
,
and
he
saw
Hetty
in
the
sunshine
 
a
sunshine
without
glare
,
with
slanting
rays
that
tremble
between
the
delicate
shadows
of
the
leaves
.
<EOS>
He
thought
,
yesterday
when
he
put
out
his
hand
to
her
as
they
came
out
of
church
,
that
there
was
a
touch
of
melancholy
kindness
in
her
face
,
such
as
he
had
not
seen
before
,
and
he
took
it
as
a
sign
that
she
had
some
sympathy
with
his
family
trouble
.
<EOS>
Poor
fellow
!
<EOS>
That
touch
of
melancholy
came
from
quite
another
source
,
but
how
was
he
to
know
?
<EOS>
We
look
at
the
one
little
woman
's
face
we
love
as
we
look
at
the
face
of
our
mother
earth
,
and
see
all
sorts
of
answers
to
our
own
yearnings
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
for
Adam
not
to
feel
that
what
had
happened
in
the
last
week
had
brought
the
prospect
of
marriage
nearer
to
him
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
he
had
felt
keenly
the
danger
that
some
other
man
might
step
in
and
get
possession
of
Hetty
's
heart
and
hand
,
while
he
himself
was
still
in
a
position
that
made
him
shrink
from
asking
her
to
accept
him
.
<EOS>
Even
if
he
had
had
a
strong
hope
that
she
was
fond
of
him
 
and
his
hope
was
far
from
being
strong
 
<EOS>
he
had
been
too
heavily
burdened
with
other
claims
to
provide
a
home
for
himself
and
Hetty
 
<EOS>
a
home
such
as
he
could
expect
her
to
be
content
with
after
the
comfort
and
plenty
of
the
Farm
.
<EOS>
Like
all
strong
natures
,
Adam
had
confidence
in
his
ability
to
achieve
something
in
the
future
;
he
felt
sure
he
should
some
day
,
if
he
lived
,
be
able
to
maintain
a
family
and
make
a
good
broad
path
for
himself
;
but
he
had
too
cool
a
head
not
to
estimate
to
the
full
the
obstacles
that
were
to
be
overcome
.
<EOS>
And
the
time
would
be
so
long
!
<EOS>
And
there
was
Hetty
,
like
a
bright
-
cheeked
apple
hanging
over
the
orchard
wall
,
within
sight
of
everybody
,
and
everybody
must
long
for
her
!
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
if
she
loved
him
very
much
,
she
would
be
content
to
wait
for
him
:
but
DID
she
love
him
?
<EOS>
His
hopes
had
never
risen
so
high
that
he
had
dared
to
ask
her
.
<EOS>
He
was
clear
-
sighted
enough
to
be
aware
that
her
uncle
and
aunt
would
have
looked
kindly
on
his
suit
,
and
indeed
,
without
this
encouragement
he
would
never
have
persevered
in

the
Farm
;
but

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

Adam

<EOS>
Yet

the

<EOS>
The
Night
-
School
and
the
Schoolmaster
  
Bartle
Massey
's
was

houses

the

,
which
was

to

.
<EOS>
Adam

in

;

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
When
he
entered
,
a
reading

was

and
Bartle
Massey
merely

,
leaving
him
to

where

.
<EOS>
He

to
-

,
and

too

,

's

,

to

with

till

<EOS>
was
over
;
so
he

.
<EOS>
It
was

which
Adam
had
beheld

;
he

's

which

's

,

before

;

above

pegs
for

;

of

that
hung

;

had
long
ago

in

the

had

;
and

<EOS>
Going

<EOS>
THE

"

Lydia

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
The
Dance
  
ARTHUR
had
chosen
the
entrance
-
hall
for
the
ballroom
:
very
wisely
,
for
no
other
room
could
have
been
so
airy
,
or
would
have
had
the
advantage
of
the
wide
doors
opening
into
the
garden
,
as
well
as
a
ready
entrance
into
the
other
rooms
.
<EOS>
To
be
sure
,
a
stone
floor
was
not
the
pleasantest
to
dance
on
,
but
then
,
most
of
the
dancers
had
known
what
it
was
to
enjoy
a
Christmas
dance
on
kitchen
quarries
.
<EOS>
It
was
one
of
those
entrance
-
halls
which
make
the
surrounding
rooms
look
like
closets
 
with
stucco
angels
,
trumpets
,
and
flower
-
wreaths
on
the
lofty
ceiling
,
and
great
medallions
of
miscellaneous
heroes
on
the
walls
,
alternating
with
statues
in
niches
.
<EOS>
Just
the
sort
of
place
to
be
ornamented
well
with
green
boughs
,
and
Mr.
Craig
had
been
proud
to
show
his
taste
and
his
hothouse
plants
on
the
occasion
.
<EOS>
The
broad
steps
of
the
stone
staircase
were
covered
with
cushions
to
serve
as
seats
for
the
children
,
who
were
to
stay
till
half
-
past
nine
with
the
servant
-
maids
to
see
the
dancing
,
and
as
this
dance
was
confined
to
the
chief
tenants
,
there
was
abundant
room
for
every
one
.
<EOS>
The
lights
were
charmingly
disposed
in
coloured
-
paper
lamps
,
high
up
among
green
boughs
,
and
the
farmers
'
wives
and
daughters
,
as
they
peeped
in
,
believed
no
scene
could
be
more
splendid
;
they
knew
now
quite
well
in
what
sort
of
rooms
the
king
and
queen
lived
,
and
their
thoughts
glanced
with
some
pity
towards
cousins
and
acquaintances
who
had
not
this
fine
opportunity
of
knowing
how
things
went
on
in
the
great
world
.
<EOS>
The
lamps
were
already
lit
,
though
the
sun
had
not
long
set
,
and
there
was
that
calm
light
out
of
doors
in
which
we
seem
to
see
all
objects
more
distinctly
than
in
the
broad
day
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
pretty
scene
outside
the
house
:
the
farmers
and
their
families
were
moving
about
the
lawn
,
among
the
flowers
and
shrubs
,
or
along
the
broad
straight
road
leading
from
the
east
front
,
where
a
carpet
of
mossy
grass
spread
on
each
side
,
studded
here
and
there
with
a
dark
flat
-
boughed
cedar
,
or
a
grand
pyramidal
fir
sweeping
the
ground
with
its
branches
,
all
tipped
with
a
fringe
of
paler
green
.
<EOS>
The
groups
of
cottagers
in
the
park
were
gradually
diminishing
,
the
young
ones
being
attracted
towards
the
lights
that
were
beginning
to
gleam
from
the
windows
of
the
gallery
in
the
abbey
,
which
was
to
be
their
dancing
-
room
,
and
some
of
the
sober
elder
ones
thinking
it
time
to
go
home
quietly
.
<EOS>
One
of
these
was
Lisbeth
Bede
,
and
Seth
went
with
her
 
not
from
filial
attention
only
,
for
his
conscience
would
not
let
him
join
in
dancing
.
<EOS>
It
had
been
rather
a
melancholy
day
to
Seth
:
<EOS>
Dinah
had
never
been
more
constantly
present
with
him
than
in
this
scene
,
where
everything
was
so
unlike
her
.
<EOS>
He
saw
her
all
the
more
vividly
after
looking
at
the
thoughtless
faces
and
gay
-
coloured
dresses
of
the
young
women
 
just
as
one
feels
the
beauty
and
the

of
a

Madonna
the
more
when
it
has
been
for

screened
from

by
a

.
<EOS>
But
this
presence
of
Dinah
in
his

to
bear
the
better
with
his
mother
's
mood
,
which
had
been
becoming
more
and
more

for
the
last
hour
.
<EOS>
Poor
Lisbeth
was
suffering
from
a
strange
conflict
of
feelings
.
<EOS>
Her
joy
and
pride
in
the
honour
paid
to
her
darling
son

;

,

-

,

.
  
<EOS>
Pity

!
<EOS>
Then

thick

.
<EOS>
That
merry

<EOS>
,

of
the
hand
 
where

?
<EOS>
That

of

,

,
remembering

youth
,
not

proud
of
the
young

by
their
side
 
<EOS>
that
holiday
sprightliness
of
portly

little

,
as

were
come
again
 
<EOS>
those
lads
and
lasses
a

,

,
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
There

but
one

mar
Martin
Poyser
's

in
this

:
<EOS>
it
was
that
he
was
always
in

with
Luke
Britton
,
that
slovenly

.
<EOS>
He
thought

in

;
but
then
,

Miss

was

the

Luke
,
he
might

.
<EOS>
So

gave

up

,

.
  
<EOS>
How
Hetty
's
heart
beat
as
Arthur
approached

!
<EOS>
He
had
hardly

at

to
-
day
:
now

must

.
<EOS>
Would

?
<EOS>
Would

?
<EOS>
She
thought

would

.
<EOS>
Now

was
there
 
<EOS>
he
had

hand
 
<EOS>
yes
,
he
was

.
<EOS>
Hetty
turned

as

for

and
met

,
before
the

carried

.
<EOS>
That

came

Arthur
like

a

pain
,
which
clung

him
,
though
he
must

and

and

the

.
<EOS>
Hetty
would
look
so
,
when
he
told

what
he
had
to
tell

;
and
he
should
never
be
able
to
bear
it
 
<EOS>
he
should
be
a
fool
and
give

again
.
<EOS>
Hetty
's
look
did
not
really
mean
so
much
as
he
thought
:
it
was
only
the
sign
of

between
the
desire
for
him
to
notice
her
and
the
dread
lest
she
should
betray
the
desire
to
others
.
<EOS>
But
Hetty
's
face
had
a
language
that
transcended
her
feelings
.
<EOS>
There
are
faces
which
nature
charges
with
a
meaning
and
pathos
not
belonging
to
the
single
human
soul
that
flutters
beneath
them
,
but
speaking
the
joys
and
sorrows
of
foregone
generations
 
eyes
that
tell
of
deep
love
which
doubtless
has
been
and
is
somewhere
,
but
not
paired
with
these
eyes
 
perhaps
paired
with
pale
eyes
that
can
say
nothing
;
just
as
a
national
language
may
be
instinct
with
poetry
unfelt
by
the
lips
that
use

.
<EOS>
That

of
Hetty
's
oppressed
Arthur
with
a
dread
which
yet
had
something
of
a
terrible
unconfessed
delight
in
it
,
that
she
loved
him
too
well
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
hard
task
before
him
,
for

that

he
felt
he
would
have
given
up

of
his
youth
for
the
happiness
of
abandoning

without

to
his
passion

Hetty
.
  
<EOS>
These
were
the
incongruous
thoughts
in
his
mind
as
he
led
Mrs.
Poyser
,
who
was
panting
with
fatigue
,
and
secretly
resolving
that
neither
judge
nor
jury
should
force
her
to

another

,
to

-
room
,
where

was

out
for

to

as

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
've
desired

to
remember
as

's
got

wi
'
you
,
sir
,
"
said

;
"
for

's

go
an
'

dance
.
<EOS>
So
I
told
her
not
to
promise
too
many
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Thank
you
,
Mrs.
Poyser
,
"
said
Arthur
,
not
without
a
twinge
.
<EOS>
"
Now
,
sit
down
in
this
comfortable
chair
,
and
here
is
Mills
ready
to
give
you
what
you
would
like
best
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
hurried
away
to
seek
another
matronly
partner
,
for
due
honour
must
be
paid
to
the
married
women
before
he
asked
any
of
the
young
ones
;
and
the
country
-
dances
,
and
the
stamping
,
and
the
gracious
nodding
,
and
the
waving
of
the
hands
,
went
on
joyously
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
the
time
had
come
for
the
fourth
dance
 
longed
for
by
the
strong
,
grave
Adam
,
as
if
he
had
been
a
delicate
-
handed
youth
of
eighteen
;
for
we
are
all
very
much
alike
when
we
are
in
our
first
love
;
and
Adam
had
hardly
ever
touched
Hetty
's
hand
for
more
than
a
transient
greeting
 
had
never
danced
with
her
but
once
before
.
<EOS>
His
eyes
had
followed
her
eagerly
to
-
night
in
spite
of
himself
,
and
had
taken
in
deeper
draughts
of
love
.
<EOS>
He
thought
she
behaved
so
prettily
,
so
quietly
;
she
did
not
seem
to
be
flirting
at
all
she
smiled
less
than
usual
;
there
was
almost
a
sweet
sadness
about
her
.
"
<EOS>
God
bless
her
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
inwardly
;
"
I
'd
make
her
life
a
happy
'
un
,
if
a
strong
arm
to
work
for
her
,
and
a
heart
to
love
her
,
could
do
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
then
there
stole
over
him
delicious
thoughts
of
coming
home
from
work
,
and
drawing
Hetty
to
his
side
,
and
feeling
her
cheek
softly
pressed
against
his
,
till
he
forgot
where
he
was
,
and
the
music
and
the
tread
of
feet
might
have
been
the
falling
of
rain
and
the
roaring
of
the
wind
,
for
what
he
knew
.
  
<EOS>
But
now
the
third
dance
was
ended
,
and
he
might
go
up
to
her
and
claim
her
hand
.
<EOS>
She
was
at
the
far
end
of
the
hall
near
the
staircase
,
whispering
with
Molly
,
<EOS>
who
had
just
given
the
sleeping
Totty
into
her
arms
before
running
to
fetch
shawls
and
bonnets
from
the
landing
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Poyser
had
taken
the
two
boys
away
into
the
dining
-
room
to
give
them
some
cake
before
they
went
home
in
the
cart
with
Grandfather
and
Molly
was
to
follow
as
fast
as
possible
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
hold
her
,
"
said
Adam
,
as
Molly
turned
upstairs
;
"
the
children
are
so
heavy
when
they
're
asleep
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hetty
was
glad
of
the
relief
,
for
to
hold
Totty
in
her
arms
,
standing
,
was
not
at
all
a
pleasant
variety
to
her
.
<EOS>
But
this
second
transfer
had
the
unfortunate

of
rousing
Totty
,
who
was
not
behind
any
child
of
her
age
in
peevishness
at
an
unseasonable

.
<EOS>
While
Hetty
was
in
the
act
of
placing
her
in
Adam
's
arms
,
and
had
not
yet
withdrawn

own
,
Totty
opened
her

,
and
forthwith
fought
out
with
her
left
fist
at
Adam
's
arm
,
and
with
her
right
caught
at
the
string
of
brown
beads
round
Hetty
's
neck
.
<EOS>
The
locket
leaped
out
from
her
frock
,
and
the
next
moment
the
string
was
broken
,
and
Hetty
,
helpless
,
saw
beads
and
locket
scattered
wide
on
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
locket
,
my
locket
!
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
in
a
loud
frightened
whisper
to
Adam
;
"
never
mind
the
beads
.
"
  
<EOS>
Adam
had
already
seen
where
the
locket
fell
,
for
it
had
attracted
his
glance
as
it
leaped
out
of
her
frock
.
<EOS>
It
had
fallen
on
the
raised
wooden
dais
where
the
band
sat
,
not
on
the
stone

;
and
as
Adam
picked
it

,
he
saw
the
glass
with

dark
and

locks
of
hair
under

.
<EOS>
It
had
fallen
that
side
upwards
,
so
the
glass
was
not
broken
.
<EOS>
He
turned
it
over
on
his
hand
,
and
saw
the
enamelled
gold
back
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
n't
hurt
,
"
he
said
,
as
he
held

towards
Hetty
,
who
was
unable
to
take

because
both

were
occupied
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
does
n't
matter
,
I
do
n't

,
"
said
Hetty
,
who
had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

?
"

Adam
,

.
<EOS>
"
You
seemed
very

about
it
.
<EOS>
I
'll
hold
it
till
you
're
ready
to
take

,
"
he

,
quietly

,
that
she
might

.
  
<EOS>
By
this

Molly
had
come
with
bonnet

,
and
as

she
had
taken
Totty
,
Adam
placed
the
locket
in

's

.
<EOS>
She
took
it
with
an
air
of

and
put
it
in
her

,
in
her
heart
vexed

with
Adam
because
he
had
seen

,
but
determined
now
that

.
  
<EOS>
"
See
,
"
she

,
"
they
're

to

;
let

.
"
  
<EOS>
Adam
assented
silently
.
<EOS>
A
puzzled
alarm
had
taken
possession
of
him
.
<EOS>
Had
Hetty
a
lover
he
did
n't
know
of
?
<EOS>
For
none
of
her
relations
,
he
was
sure
,
would
give
her
a
locket
like
that
;
and
none
of
her
admirers
,
with
whom
he
was
acquainted
,
was
in
the
position
of
an
accepted
lover
,
as
the
giver
of
that
locket
must
be
.
<EOS>
Adam
was
lost
in
the
utter
impossibility
of
finding
any
person
for
his
fears
to
alight
on
.
<EOS>
He
could
only
feel
with
a
terrible
pang
that
there
was
something
in
Hetty
's
life
unknown
to

;
that
while

had
been
rocking
himself
in
the
hope
that
she
would
come
to
love
him
,
she
was
already
loving
another
.
<EOS>
The
pleasure
of
the
dance
with
Hetty
was
gone
;
his
eyes
,
when
they
rested
on
her
,
had
an
uneasy
questioning
expression
in
them
;
he
could
think
of
nothing
to
say
to
her
;
and
she
too
was
out
of
temper
and
disinclined
to
speak
.
<EOS>
They
were
both
glad
when
the
dance
was
ended
.
  
<EOS>
Adam
was
determined
to
stay
no
longer
;
no
one
wanted
him
,
and
no
one
would
notice
if
he
slipped
away
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
got
out
of
doors
,
he
began
to

at

,
hurrying

without

why
,
busy
with
the
painful

that
the
memory
of
this

,
so
full
of
honour
and

to

,
was
poisoned
for

.
<EOS>
Suddenly
,
when
he
was
far
on
through
the
Chase
,
he
stopped
,
startled
by
a
flash
of
reviving

.
<EOS>
After
all
,
he
might
be
a
fool
,
making
a
great
misery
out
of
a
trifle
.
<EOS>
Hetty
,
fond
of
finery
as
she
was
,
might
have
bought
the
thing
herself
.
<EOS>
It
looked
too
expensive
for
that
 
<EOS>
it
looked
like
the
things
on
white
satin
in
the
great
jeweller
's
shop
at
Rosseter
.
<EOS>
But
Adam
had
very
imperfect
notions
of
the
value
of
such
things
,
and
he
thought
it
could
certainly
not
cost
more
than
a
guinea
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
Hetty
had
had
as
much
as
that
in
Christmas
boxes
,
and
there
was
no
knowing
<EOS>
but
she
might
have
been
childish
enough
to
spend
it
in
that
way
;
she
was
such
a
young
thing
,
and
she
could
n't
help
loving
finery
!
<EOS>
But
then
,
why
had
she
been
so
frightened
about
it
at
first
,
and
changed

,
and

?
<EOS>
Oh
,
that
was
because
she
was

of
his
seeing
that

had
such

smart
thing
 
<EOS>
she
was
conscious

it

wrong
for

to

on

,
and
she
knew
that
Adam
disapproved
of

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
proof
she
cared
about
what
he
liked
and
disliked
.
<EOS>
She
must
have
thought
from
his

and
gravity
afterwards
that

with

,
that

.
<EOS>
And
as
he
walked
on
more
quietly
,
chewing

cud

this
new
hope
,
his
only

was
that
he
had
behaved
in
a
way
which
might
chill
Hetty
's

towards
him
.
<EOS>
For
this
last
view
of
the
matter
must
be
the
true

.
<EOS>
How
could
Hetty
have
an
accepted
lover
,
quite
unknown
to
him
?
<EOS>
She
was
never
away
from
her
uncle
's
house
for
more
than
a
day
;
she
could
have
no
acquaintances
that
did
not
come
there
,
and
no
intimacies
unknown
to
her
uncle
and
aunt
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
folly
to
believe
that
the
locket
was

to

by

.
<EOS>
The

dark

he

;
he

,

.
<EOS>
It
might

a
bit
of
her
father
's
or
mother
's
,
who
had
died
when
she
was
a
child
,
and
she
would
naturally
put
a
bit
of
her
own
along

.
  
<EOS>
And
so
Adam
went
to
bed

,

an

of
probabilities
 
the
surest
screen
a
wise

can

.
<EOS>
His
last

melted
into

that

was

again

the
Hall
Farm
,
and
that

.
  
<EOS>
And

he

,
Arthur
was

to

,
"
I
shall
be
in
the
wood

day

to
-
morrow

seven
;
come
as
early
as
you
can
.
"
<EOS>
And
Hetty
's

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
She
was
happy
for
the
first

this
long

,
and
wished

last

.
<EOS>
Arthur
wished

;
it
was

he

to

;
and
a
man
never
lies

than
when
he
has

that
he
shall
subdue

to
-
morrow
.
  
<EOS>
But

's

,

as

to
-

's

.
<EOS>
Now

had
done

,
Mr.

,

,

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>
Going

,

?
<EOS>
"

,

"

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
A

<EOS>
IT
was
beyond
the
middle
of
August
 
nearly

.
<EOS>
The

of

wheat
had

in
our
north

of
Loamshire
,
but
the
harvest
was
likely
still
to
be

by

heavy

,
which
were
causing

and
much

.
<EOS>
From
this
last
trouble
the
Broxton
and
Hayslope
farmers
,
on
their
pleasant
uplands
and
in
their
brook

,
had
not

,
and
as
I

not

such

as

better

,

about

,
so

hope

gathering
in
their
own
corn

;
and
occasional

flattered

.
  
<EOS>
The
eighteenth
of

was
one

these

when
the

brighter

all

for

.
<EOS>
Grand

,

;

,

;

<EOS>
And

wind

only
part

.
<EOS>
A

for

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

!
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
The

,

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
A

Adam
's
,

,

<EOS>
And

;

;

.
<EOS>
These

:

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

Grove
.
<EOS>
What
grand

!
<EOS>
Adam
delighted
in
a
fine
tree
of
all

;
as
the

's

is
keenest
on

sea
,
so
Adam
's

were

.
<EOS>
He
kept

in

,

,

flecks
and

in

,

,
and
had
often

of

,

.
<EOS>
No

only

nay
,

later

.

"
What

"

"

<EOS>

wo

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
You

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,

,
"
I

I
wo

.
<EOS>
Do

want
provoking
any

?
<EOS>
I
tell

you
're

,

.
"
  
<EOS>
The
colour
had

back

's

;
in

right

was

,

,

.
<EOS>
His

was
as

Adam
's
now
,
and

,

the

that
had

,

of
panthers
in

by

.
<EOS>
The
delicate
-
handed
gentleman
was
a
match
for
the
workman
in
everything
but
strength
,
and
Arthur
's
skill
enabled
him
to

for
some

.
<EOS>
But
between
unarmed

is
to

strong
,
where

strong
is
no

,
and
Arthur
must

well
-
planted

's
as

by

.
<EOS>
The
blow
soon

,
and
Arthur
fell
,

,
so
that
Adam
could
only
discern

.
  
<EOS>
He
stood
still

dim

Arthur
to
rise
.
  
<EOS>
The

had
been
given
now
,
towards

he
had

all
the
force
of
nerve

and
what

?
<EOS>
What

done

?
<EOS>
Only
satisfied

own

,

.
<EOS>
He

not

Hetty
,
nor
changed

past
 
there
<EOS>
it
was
,
just

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
But
why
did
not
Arthur
rise
?
<EOS>
He
was
perfectly

,
and
the

.
<EOS>
Good

!
<EOS>
had

<EOS>
Adam

,

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

.
    
<EOS>
A
Dilemma
  
<EOS>
IT

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

?

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Adam

.
<EOS>
Yet

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

<EOS>

<EOS>
So

.
<EOS>
Arthur

<EOS>
The
Next
Morning
  
ARTHUR

not

;
he

.
<EOS>
For

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
In

:

,
though

be
but

has
a
present
which
offers
some
resistance
to
the
past
 
sensations
which
assert

against

.
<EOS>
And

,

certainly

found
that
in

regret

,

.
<EOS>
Arthur

that

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
For

sunk

as

<EOS>
makes

.
  
<EOS>
Arthur
's
,

,

.
<EOS>
Deeds

:

the

.
<EOS>
He
did

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
He
had

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Arthur

<EOS>

<EOS>
Nemesis

the

open
between
Adam
and
Hetty
.
<EOS>
Her
heart
might
really

to
Adam
,
as

said
,
after

;
and
in

no

,
since

Adam

.
<EOS>
To

,

was

wrong
if

.
<EOS>
That
was
a

that
marred
the
consoling

.
<EOS>
Arthur
's
cheeks
even
burned
in
mingled

.
<EOS>
But
what

?
<EOS>
He
was
bound

to

:
his
first

was
to
guard

.
<EOS>
He
would
never
have
told

a

on

own

.
<EOS>
Good
God
!
<EOS>
What
a

he

to

;
and

,

,

had
.
<EOS>
(
Pity
that

!
)
  
<EOS>
Well

<EOS>

;

;

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

:

<EOS>
The

Letter
  
<EOS>
THE
next
Sunday
Adam
joined

Poysers
on

,
hoping

an

to
go
home

.
<EOS>
He
had
the
letter

,
and
was

to
have
an

of
talking

Hetty
alone
.
<EOS>
He
could
not

her
face
at

,
for

had
changed
her
seat
,
and
when

,

was

and

.
<EOS>
He
expected

,

seen

with
Arthur
in

Grove
.
  
<EOS>
"
Come
,

,
Adam
,
"

;
and

fields

to

.
<EOS>
The
children
soon

:
  
"

,

?
<EOS>
I
've
something
partic'lar

about
.
"
  
<EOS>
Hetty
said
,
"
Very
well
.
<EOS>
"
She
was

as

as
Adam
was
that
she
should

some

with

.
<EOS>
She
wondered
what
he
thought
of
her
and
Arthur
.
<EOS>
He
must
have
seen
them
kissing
,
she
knew
,
but
she
had
no
conception
of
the
scene

had

Arthur
and
Adam
.
<EOS>
Her
first

had
been
that
Adam
would
be
very

her
,
and
perhaps

tell
her
aunt
and
uncle
,
but

never

that

would
dare

Donnithorne
.
<EOS>
It

behaved

her
to

day
,
and

,

was

lest

should
mean
"
to
tell
.
<EOS>
"
But
,

.
<EOS>
She

that

;

;

,

.
<EOS>
Besides

MUST

Adam
,
lest

.
  
<EOS>
Hetty

his
about

many

.
<EOS>
And

,

,

,

the

;
and
,

,

.
<EOS>
So
,

rest

,

's

,
and

her
small

little

honest
Adam
's

.
<EOS>
For

,

,
who

to

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

was
not
much
the
less
because

felt

unhappy
all

.
<EOS>
The

Arthur
was
a

to
her
 
mingling

passion

vanity
<EOS>

shape

.
<EOS>
She

hopeful

Arthur

<EOS>
"
I

"
<EOS>

and

secret
 
that

all

<EOS>
was

.
<EOS>
She

.

,

"

or
two
.
"
  
<EOS>
As
Adam
was
getting
over
a
stile
at
this
point
in
his
reflections
,
he
perceived
a
man

along

field
before

.
<EOS>
He
knew
it
was
Seth
,
returning
from
an
evening
preaching
,
and
made
haste
to
overtake
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
thee'dst
be
at
home
before
me
,
"
he
said
,
as
Seth
turned
round
to

,
"
for
I
'm
later
than
usual
to
-
night
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
I
'm
later

,
for
I
got
into

,

,
with
John
Barnes
,
who
has

in
a

,
and
I
'd
a
question
to

about
his

.
<EOS>
It
's
one
<EOS>
o
'
them
subjects
that
lead
you
further
than
y
'
expect
 
they
do
n't
lie
along
the
straight
road
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
walked
along
together
in

two
or

.
<EOS>
Adam
was
not

to
enter
into
the

of
religious

,
but
he
was

to

of

with
Seth
.
<EOS>
That
was
a
rare
impulse
in
him
,
much
as
the
brothers
loved
each

.
<EOS>
They
hardly
ever
spoke
of
personal

,
or

more
than

to

.
<EOS>
Adam
was
by

reserved
in
all

of

,
and
Seth

a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Seth
,
lad
,
<EOS>
"
Adam

,

,
"

Morris

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
She
told

I
might

after

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

;

.

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

,

?

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
a

-

<EOS>
i
'

'
.
"
  
<EOS>
Adam
,
meanwhile
,
was
reading
Dinah
's
letter
by
the
light
of
his
dip
candle
.
   
<EOS>
DEAR
BROTHER
SETH
 
<EOS>
Your
letter
lay
three
days
beyond
my
knowing
of
it
at
the
post
,
for
I
had
not
money
enough
by
me
to
pay
the
carriage
,
<EOS>
this
being
a
time
of
great
need
and
sickness
here
,
with
the
rains
that
have
fallen
,
as
if
the
windows
of
heaven
were
opened
again
;
and
to
lay
by
money
,
from
day
to
day
,
in
such
a
time
,
when
there
are
so
many
in
present
need
of
all
things
,
would
be
a
want
of
trust
like
the
laying
up
of
the
manna
.
<EOS>
I
speak
of
this
,
because
I
would
not
have
you
think
me
slow
to
answer
,
or
that
I
had
small
joy
in
your
rejoicing
at
the
worldly
good
that
has
befallen
your
brother
Adam
.
<EOS>
The
honour
and
love
you
bear
him
is
nothing
but
meet
,
for
God
has
given
him
great
gifts
,
and
he
uses
them
as
the
patriarch
Joseph
did
,
who
,
when
he
was
exalted
to
a
place
of
power
and
trust
,
yet
yearned
with
tenderness
towards
his
parent
and
his
younger
brother
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
heart
is
knit
to
your
aged
mother
since
it
was
granted
me
to
be
near
her
in
the
day
of
trouble
.
<EOS>
Speak
to
her
of
me
,
and
tell
her
I
often
bear
her
in
my
thoughts
at
evening
time
,
when
I
am
sitting
in
the
dim
light
as
I
did
with
her
,
and
we
held
one
another
's
hands
,
and
I
spoke
the
words
of
comfort
that
were
given
to
me
.
<EOS>
Ah
,
that
is
a
blessed
time
,
is
n't
it
,
Seth
,
when
the
outward
light
is
fading
,
and
the
body
is
a
little
wearied
with
its
work
and
its
labour
.
<EOS>
Then
the
inward
light
shines
the
brighter
,
and
we
have
a
deeper
sense
of
resting
on
the
Divine
strength
.
<EOS>
I
sit
on
my
chair
in
the
dark
room
and
close
my
eyes
,
and
it
is
as
if
I
was
out
of
the
body
and
could
feel
no
want
for
evermore
.
<EOS>
For
then
,
the
very
hardship
,
and
the
sorrow
,
and
the
blindness
,
and
the
sin
I
have
beheld
and
been
ready
to
weep
over
 
yea
,
all
the
anguish
of
the
children
of
men
,
which
sometimes
wraps
me
round
like
sudden
darkness
 
I
can
bear
with
a
willing
pain
,
as
if
I
was
sharing
the
Redeemer
's
cross
.
<EOS>
For
I
feel
it
<EOS>
,
I
feel
it
 
infinite
love
is
suffering
too
 
yea
,
in
the
fulness
of
knowledge
<EOS>
it
suffers
,
it
yearns
,
it
mourns
;
and
that
is
a
blind
self
-
seeking
which
wants
to
be
freed
from
the
sorrow
wherewith
the
whole
creation
groaneth
and
travaileth
.
<EOS>
Surely
it
is
not
true
blessedness
to
be
free
from
sorrow
,
while
there
is
sorrow
and
sin
in
the
world
:
sorrow
is
then
a
part
of
love
,
and
love
does
not
seek
to
throw
it
off
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
the
spirit
only
that
tells
me
this
 
<EOS>
I
see
it
in
the
whole
work
and
word
of
the
Gospel
.
<EOS>
Is
there
not
pleading
in
heaven
?
<EOS>
Is
not
the
Man
of
Sorrows
there
in
that
crucified
body
wherewith
he
ascended
?
<EOS>
And
is
He
not
one
with
the
Infinite
Love
itself
 
as
our
love
is
one
with
our
sorrow
?
  
<EOS>
"
These
thoughts
have
been
much
borne
in
on
me
of
late
,
and
I
have
seen
with
new
clearness
the
meaning
of
those
words
,
"
If
any
man
love
me
,
let
him
take
up
my
cross
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
heard
this
enlarged
on
as
if
it
meant
the
troubles
and
persecutions
we
bring
on
ourselves
by
confessing
Jesus
.
<EOS>
But
surely
that
is
a
narrow
thought
.
<EOS>
The
true
cross
of
the
Redeemer
was
the
sin
and
sorrow
of
this
world
 
<EOS>
that
was
what
lay
heavy
on
his
heart
 
<EOS>
and
that
is
the
cross
we
shall
share
with
him
<EOS>
,
that
is
the
cup
we
must
drink
of
with
him
,
if
we
would
have
any
part
in
that
Divine
Love
which
is
one
with
his
sorrow
.
  
<EOS>
"
In
my
outward
lot
,
which
you
ask
about
,
I
have
all
things
and
abound
.
<EOS>
I
have
had
constant
work
in
the
mill
,
though
some
of
the
other
hands
have
been
turned
off
for
a
time
,
and
my
body
is
greatly
strengthened
,
so
that
I
feel
little
weariness
after
long
walking
and
speaking
.
<EOS>
What
you
say
about
staying
in
your
own
country
with
your
mother
and
brother
shows
me
that
you
have
a
true
guidance
;
your
lot
is
appointed
there
by
a
clear
showing
,
and
to
seek
a
greater
blessing
elsewhere
would
be
like
laying
a
false
offering
on
the
altar
and
expecting
the
fire
from
heaven
to
kindle
it
.
<EOS>
My
work
and
my
joy
are
here
among
the
hills
,
and
I
sometimes
think
I
cling
too
much
to
my
life
among
the
people
here
,
and
should
be
rebellious
if
I
was
called
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
was
thankful
for
your
tidings
about
the
dear
friends
at
the
Hall
Farm
,
for
though
I
sent
them
a
letter
,
by
my
aunt
's
desire
,
after
I
came
back
from
my
sojourn
among
them
,
I
have
had
no
word
from
them
.
<EOS>
My
aunt
has
not
the
pen
of
a
ready
writer
,
and
the
work
of
the
house
is
sufficient
for
the
day
,
for
she
is
weak
in
body
.
<EOS>
My
heart
cleaves
to
her
and
her
children
as
the
nearest
of
all
to
me
in
the
flesh
 
yea
,
and
to
all
in
that
house
.
<EOS>
I
am
carried
away
to
them
continually
in
my
sleep
,
and
often
in
the
midst
of
work
,
and
even
of
speech
,
the
thought
of
them
is
borne
in
on
me
as
if
they
were
in
need
and
trouble
,
which
yet
is
dark
to
me
.
<EOS>
There
may
be
some
leading
here
;
but
I
wait
to
be
taught
.
<EOS>
You
say
they
are
all
well
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
shall
see
each
other
again
in
the
body
,
I
trust
,
though
,
it
may
be
,
not
for
a
long
while
;
for
the
brethren
and
sisters
at
Leeds
are
desirous
to
have
me
for
a
short
space
among
them
,
when
I
have
a
door
opened
me
again
to
leave
Snowfield
.
  
<EOS>
"
Farewell
,
dear
brother
 
and
yet
not
farewell
.
<EOS>
For
those
children
of
God
whom
it
has
been
granted
to
see
each
other
face
to
face
,
and
to
hold
communion
together
,
and
to
feel
the
same
spirit
working
in
both
can
never
more
be
sundered
though
the
hills
may
lie
between
.
<EOS>
For
their
souls
are
enlarged
for
evermore
by
that
union
,
and
they
bear
one
another
about
in
their
thoughts
continually
as
it
were
a
new
strength
.
 
<EOS>
Your
faithful
Sister
and
fellow
-
worker
in
Christ
,
  
"
DINAH
MORRIS
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
"

not

but

.
<EOS>
She

.
"
   
<EOS>
Adam

"

"
  
"
