<EOS>
In
Hetty
's
Bed
-
Chamber
  
<EOS>
IT
was
no
longer
light
enough
to
go
to
bed
without
a
candle
,
even
in
Mrs.
Poyser
's
early
household
,
and
Hetty
carried
one
with
her
as
she
went
up
at
last
to
her
bedroom
soon
after
Adam
was
gone
,
and
bolted
the
door
behind
her
.
  
<EOS>
Now
she
would
read
her
letter
.
<EOS>
It
must
 
it
must
have
comfort
in
it
.
<EOS>
How
was
Adam
to
know
the
truth
?
<EOS>
It
was
always
likely
he
should
say
what
he
did
say
.
  
<EOS>
She
set
down
the
candle
and
took
out
the
letter
.
<EOS>
It
had
a
faint
scent
of
roses
,
which
made
her
feel
as
if
Arthur
were
close
to
her
.
<EOS>
She
put
it
to
her
lips
,
and
a
rush
of
remembered
sensations
for
a
moment
or
two
swept
away
all
fear
.
<EOS>
But
her
heart
began
to
flutter
strangely
,
and
her
hands
to
tremble
as
she
broke
the
seal
.
<EOS>
She
read
slowly
;
it
was
not
easy
for
her
to
read
a
gentleman
's
handwriting
,
though
Arthur
had
taken
pains
to
write
plainly
.
   
<EOS>
"
DEAREST
HETTY
 
<EOS>
I
have
spoken
truly
when
I
have
said
that
I
loved
you
,
and
I
shall
never
forget
our
love
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
your
true
friend
as
long
as
life
lasts
,
and
I
hope
to
prove
this
to
you
in
many
ways
.
<EOS>
If
I
say
anything
to
pain
you
in
this
letter
,
do
not
believe
it
is
for
want
of
love
and
tenderness
towards
you
,
for
there
is
nothing
I
would
not
do
for
you
,
if
I
knew
it
to
be
really
for
your
happiness
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
bear
to
think
of
my
little
Hetty
shedding
tears
when
I
am
not
there
to
kiss
them
away
;
and
if
I
followed
only
my
own
inclinations
,
I
should
be
with
her
at
this
moment
instead
of
writing
.
<EOS>
It
is
very
hard
for
me
to
part
from
her
 
harder
still
for
me
to
write
words
which
may
seem
unkind
,
though
they
spring
from
the
truest
kindness
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
,
dear
Hetty
,
sweet
as
our
love
has
been
to
me
,
sweet
as
it
would
be
to
me
for
you
to
love
me
always
,
I
feel
that
it
would
have
been
better
for
us
both
if
we
had
never
had
that
happiness
,
and
that
it
is
my
duty
to
ask
you
to
love
me
and
care
for
me
as
little
as
you
can
.
<EOS>
The
fault
has
all
been
mine
,
for
though
I
have
been
unable
to
resist
the
longing
to
be
near
you
<EOS>
,
I
have
felt
all
the
while
that
your
affection
for
me
might
cause
you
grief
.
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
resisted
my
feelings
.
<EOS>
I
should
have
done
so
,
if
I
had
been
a
better
fellow
than
I
am
;
but
now
,
since
the
past
can
not
be
altered
,
I
am
bound
to
save
you
from
any
evil
that
I
have
power
to
prevent
.
<EOS>
And
I
feel
it
would
be
a
great
evil
for
you
if
your
affections
continued
so
fixed
on
me
that
you
could
think
of
no
other
man
who
might
be
able
to
make
you
happier
by
his
love
than
I
ever
can
,
and
if
you
continued
to
look
towards
something
in
the
future
which
can
not
possibly
happen
.
<EOS>
For
,
dear
Hetty
,
if
I
were
to
do
what
you
one
day
spoke
of
,
and
make
you
my
wife
,
I
should
do
what
you
yourself
would
come
to
feel
was
for
your
misery
instead
of
your
welfare
.
<EOS>
I
know
you
can
never
be
happy
except
by
marrying
a
man
in
your
own
station
;
and
if
I
were
to
marry
you
now
,
I
should
only
be
adding
to
any
wrong
I
have
done
,
besides
offending

my
duty
in
the
other

life
.
<EOS>
You
know
nothing
,
dear
Hetty
,
of
the
world
in
which
I
must
always

,
and
you
would
soon

to
dislike

,
because
there

.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
since
I
can
not

,
we
must
part
 
<EOS>
we
must
try
not

.
<EOS>
I
am

I

,
but
nothing
else

.
<EOS>
Be
angry

,
my
sweet
one
,
I
deserve

;
but
do
not

that
I
shall
not
always

for
you
 
<EOS>
always
be
grateful
to
you
 
<EOS>
always
remember
my
Hetty
;
and

we

,
trust

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
told

where

are
to

letter
to
,

,
but
I

.
<EOS>
Do

something
I

really

;
for
,
dear
Hetty
,
we
must

.
<EOS>
Forgive

,
and

,

shall

,
as

,
your

"
ARTHUR
DONNITHORNE
.
"
   
<EOS>
Slowly
Hetty
had
read
this
letter
;
and
when

from

the

of
a
blanched
face
in
the
old
dim
glass
 
a

,
but
with

.
<EOS>
Hetty
did
not
see
the
face
 
<EOS>
she
saw
nothing
 
<EOS>
she
only
felt
that

was
cold

.
<EOS>
The
letter
shook
and

in

hand
.
<EOS>
She
laid

down
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
horrible
sensation
 
this
cold
and
trembling
.
<EOS>
It
swept
away
the
very
ideas
that
produced
it
,
and
Hetty
got
up
to
reach
a
warm

from
her
clothes

press
,
wrapped

round

,
and
sat
as

were

nothing
but

.
<EOS>
Presently

took

letter
with

,
and
began
to
read

through
again
.
<EOS>
The
tears
came
this
time
 
great
rushing
tears
that
blinded
her
and
blotched
the
paper
.
<EOS>
She
felt
nothing
but
that
Arthur
was
cruel
 
cruel
to
write
so
,
cruel
not
to
marry
her
.
<EOS>
Reasons
why
he
could
not
marry
her
had
no
existence
for
her
mind
;
how
could
she
believe
in
any
misery
that
could
come
to
her
from
the
fulfilment
of
all
she
had
been
longing
for
and

?
<EOS>
She
had
not
the
ideas
that
could
make

notion
of
that

.
  
<EOS>
As

letter

,
she
caught

of

face
in
the
glass
;
it
was
reddened
now
,
and
wet

;
it
was
almost
like
a
companion
that
she
might
complain
to
 
that
would
pity
her
.
<EOS>
She
leaned
forward
on
her

,
and
looked
into
those
dark
overflooding
eyes
and
at
the
quivering

,
and
saw
how
the
tears
came
thicker
and
thicker
,
and
how
the
mouth
became
convulsed

.
  
<EOS>
The
shattering
of
all
her
little
dream
-
world
,
the
crushing
blow
on
her
new
-
born
passion
,
afflicted
her
pleasure
-
craving
nature
with
an
overpowering
pain
that
annihilated
all
impulse
to
resistance
,
and
suspended
her
anger
.
<EOS>
She
sat
sobbing
till
the
candle
went
out
,
and
then
,
wearied
,
aching
,
stupefied
with
crying
,
threw
herself
on
the
bed
without

and
went
to

.
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
feeble
dawn
in
the
room
when
Hetty
awoke
,
a
little
after
four
o'clock
,
with
a
sense
of
dull
misery
,
<EOS>
the
cause
of
which
broke
upon

gradually
as
she
began
to
discern
the
objects
round

in
the
dim

.
<EOS>
And
then
came
the
frightening
thought
that
she
had
to
conceal
her

as
well
as
to
bear

,
in
this
dreary

that
was
coming
.
<EOS>
She
could
lie
no
longer
.
<EOS>
She
got
up
and
went
towards
the
table
:
there
lay
the
letter
.
<EOS>
She
opened
her
treasure
-
drawer
:
there
lay
the
ear
-
rings
and
the
locket
 
<EOS>
the
signs
of
all
her
short
happiness
 
<EOS>
the
signs
of
the
lifelong
dreariness
that
was
to
follow

.
<EOS>
Looking
at
the
little
trinkets
which
she
had
once
eyed
and
fingered
so
fondly
as
the
earnest
of
her
future
paradise
of
finery
,
she
lived
back
in
the
moments
when
they
had
been
given
to
her
with
such
tender

,
such
strangely
pretty
words
,
such
glowing
looks
,
which
filled
her
with
a
bewildering
delicious
surprise
 
<EOS>
they
were
so
much
sweeter
than
she
had
thought
anything
could
be
.
<EOS>
And
the
Arthur
who
had
spoken
to
her
and
looked
at
her
in
this
way
,
who
was
present
with
her
now
 
whose
arm
she
felt
round
her
,
his
cheek
against
hers
<EOS>
,
his
very
breath
upon
her
 
was
the
cruel
,
cruel
Arthur
who
had
written
that
letter
,
that
letter
which
she
snatched
and
crushed
and
then
opened
again
,
that
she
might
read

once
more
.
<EOS>
The
half
-
benumbed
mental
condition
which
was
the
effect
of
the
last
night
's
violent
crying
made
it
necessary
to
her
to
look
again
and
see
if
her
wretched

were
actually
true
 
if
the
letter
was
really
so
cruel
.
<EOS>
She
had
to
hold
it
close
to
the
window
,
else
she
could
not
have
read
it
by
the
faint
light
.
<EOS>
Yes
!
<EOS>
It
was
worse
 
<EOS>
it
was
more
cruel
.
<EOS>
She
crushed
it
up
again
in
anger
.
<EOS>
She
hated
the
writer
of
that
letter
 
hated
him
for
the
very
reason
that
she
hung
upon
him
with
all
her
love
 
all
the
girlish
passion
and
vanity
that
made
up
her
love
.
  
<EOS>
She
had
no
tears
this
morning
.
<EOS>
She
had
wept
them
all
away
last
night
,
and
now
she
felt
that
dry
-
eyed
morning
misery
,
which
is
worse
than
the
first
shock
because
it
has
the
future
in
it
as
well
as
the
present
.
<EOS>
Every
morning
to
come
,
as
far
as
her
imagination
could
stretch
,
she
would
have
to
get
up
and
feel
that
the
day
would
have
no
joy
for
her
.
<EOS>
For
there
is
no
despair
<EOS>
so
absolute
as
that
which
comes
with
the
first
moments
of
our
first
great
sorrow
,
when
we
have
not
yet
known
what
it
is
to
have
suffered
and
be
healed
,
to
have
despaired
and
to
have

.
<EOS>
As
Hetty
began

to
take
off
the
clothes
she
had
worn
all
the
night
,
that
she
might
wash
herself
and
brush
her
hair
,
she
had
a
sickening
sense
that
her
life
would
go
on
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
She
should
always
be
doing
things
she
had
no
pleasure
in
,
getting
up
to
the
old
tasks
of
work
,
seeing
people
she
cared
nothing
about
,
going
to
church
,
and
to
Treddleston
,
and
to
tea
with
Mrs.
Best
,
and
carrying
no
happy
thought
with
her
.
<EOS>
For
her
short
poisonous
delights
had
spoiled
for
ever
all
the
little
joys
that
had
once
made
the
sweetness
of
her
life
 
the
new
frock
ready
for
Treddleston
Fair
,
the
party
at
Mr.
Britton
's
at
Broxton
wake
,
the
beaux
that
she
would
say
"
No
"
to
for
a
long
while
,
and
the
prospect
of
the
wedding
that
was
to
come
at
last
when
she
would
have
a
silk

and
a
great
many
clothes
all
at
once
.
<EOS>
These
things
were
all
flat
and
dreary
to
her
now
;
everything
would
be
a
weariness
,
and
she
would
carry
about
for
ever
a
hopeless
thirst
and
longing
.
  
<EOS>
She
paused
in
the
midst
of
her
languid
undressing
and
leaned
against
the
dark
old
clothes
-
press
.
<EOS>
Her
neck
and
arms
were
bare
,
her
hair
hung
down
in
delicate
rings
 
<EOS>
and
they
were
just
as
beautiful
as
they
were
that
night
two
months
ago
,
when
she
walked
up
and
down
this
bed

chamber
glowing
with

and
hope
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
thinking
of
her
neck
and
arms
now
;
even
her
own
beauty
was
indifferent
to
her
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
wandered
sadly
over
the
dull
old
chamber
,
and
then
looked
out
vacantly
towards
the
growing

.
<EOS>
Did
a
remembrance
of
Dinah
come
across
her
mind
?
<EOS>
Of
her
foreboding
words
,
which
had
made

?
<EOS>
Of
Dinah
's
affectionate

to
think
of
her
as
a
friend

trouble
?
<EOS>
No
,
the
impression
had
been
too
slight
to
recur
.
<EOS>
Any
affection
or
comfort
Dinah
could
have
given

would
have
been
as
indifferent
to
Hetty
this
morning
as
everything
else
was
except
her
bruised

.
<EOS>
She
was
only
thinking
she
could
never
stay
here
and
go
on
with
the
old
life
 
she
could
better
bear
something
quite
new
than
sinking
back
into
the
old
everyday
round
.
<EOS>
She
would
like
to
run
away
that
very
morning
,
and
never
see
any
of
the
old
faces
again
.
<EOS>
But
Hetty
's
was
not
a
nature
to
face
difficulties
 
to
dare
to
loose
her
hold
on
the
familiar
and
rush
blindly
on
some
unknown
condition
.
<EOS>
Hers
was
a
luxurious
and
vain
nature
 
<EOS>
not
a
passionate
one
 
<EOS>
and
if
she
were
ever
to
take
any

measure
,
she
must

urged

by

of
terror
.
<EOS>
There
was
not
much

for

to
travel
in
the
narrow

of
her
imagination
,
and
she
soon
fixed
on
the
one

would
do
to
get

from
her
old

:
she
would
ask
her
uncle
to
let

go
to
be

's

.
<EOS>
Miss
Lydia
's
maid
would
help

to

a
situation
,
if

had
her

's

.
  
<EOS>
When

had
thought

,

began
to
wash
:
it

more

to

to

and
try

as

.
<EOS>
She
would
ask
her
uncle
this
very
day
.
<EOS>
On
Hetty
's
blooming
health

such

as
hers
to

;
and

,

.
<EOS>
But

,
that

,
hard

that

,

.
<EOS>
She

:

.
<EOS>
Nobody

,

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
That

poor
little

's

.
  
<EOS>
So

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
One

.
<EOS>
The

:

.
<EOS>
There

and

,

!
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
What
a

this
looks

,

one

along
the
valleys
and

!
<EOS>
I
have
often

so
when
,

,
where

<EOS>
our
English
Loamshire
 
<EOS>
the
rich
land
tilled

<EOS>
I

:
an

great

the

Cross
.
<EOS>
It
has

perhaps

,

by

,

;

's

.
<EOS>
He

hidden

,

,

<EOS>
perhaps

of

.

;
and
the
sound
of
the
gurgling
brook
,

would

for
your

.
<EOS>
No
wonder

's

much

:
no

he

.
  
<EOS>
Hetty

<EOS>
The
Journey
of
Hope
  
<EOS>
A
LONG
,

,

,
because
there
were
always
men
lounging
there
,
who
stared
at
her
and
joked
her
rudely
.
<EOS>
Her
body
was
very
weary
too
with
these
days
of
new
fatigue
and
anxiety
;
they
had
made
her
look
more
pale
and

than
all
the
time
of
hidden
dread
she
had

through

.
<EOS>
When

last
she
reached
Stony
Stratford
,
her

and

had

too
strong
for

;
she

for
the
rest

way
,
though

should

.
<EOS>
She
would

nothing
at
Windsor
but
to

.
<EOS>
When
she
had
paid

fare
for
the
last

,

;
and
as

in

at

,

,

to
"
remember

.
"
<EOS>
She

,

with

and

.
<EOS>
As

"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,
"

,

,
"

put

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

had

<EOS>

would

"
 
for

.
<EOS>
They

<EOS>

<EOS>
No

<EOS>

<EOS>
The
Journey
in
Despair
  
HETTY
was
too
ill
through
the
rest
of
that
day
for
any
questions
to
be
addressed
to
her
 
too
ill
even
to
think
with
any
distinctness
of
the
evils
that
were
to
come
.
<EOS>
She
only
felt
that
all
her
hope
was
crushed
,
and
that
instead
of
having
found
a
refuge
she
had
only
reached
the
borders
of
a
new
wilderness
where
no
goal
lay
before
her
.
<EOS>
The
sensations
of
bodily
sickness
,
in
a
comfortable
bed
,
and
with
the
tendance
of
the
good
-
natured
landlady
,
made
a
sort
of
respite
for
her
;
such
a
respite
as
there
is
in
the
faint

which
obliges
a
man
to
throw
himself
on
the
sand
instead
of
toiling
onward
under
the
scorching
sun
.
  
<EOS>
But
when
sleep
and
rest
had
brought
back
the
strength
necessary
for
the
keenness
of
mental
suffering
 
when
she
lay
the
next
morning
looking
at
the
growing
light
which
was
like
a
cruel
task
-
master
returning
to
urge
from
her
a
fresh
round
of
hated
hopeless
labour
 
<EOS>
she

to
think
what
course

must
take
,
to
remember
that
all
her
money
was
gone
,
to

further

among
strangers
with
the
new

shed
on

by
the
experience
of

to
Windsor
.
<EOS>
But
which
way
could
she
turn
?
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
for
her
to
enter
into
any
service
,
even
if
she
could
obtain
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
nothing
but
immediate
beggary
before
her
.
<EOS>
She
thought
of
a
young
woman
who
had
been

against

at
Hayslope
one

,
nearly

with
cold
and

a
tiny
infant

.
<EOS>
The
woman
was

and

to
the
parish
.
<EOS>
"
The
parish
!
<EOS>
"
You
can
perhaps
hardly

the
effect
of
that
word
on
a
mind

Hetty
's
,
brought
up
among
people
who
were
somewhat
hard
in
their
feelings
even

poverty
,
who
lived
among
the
fields
,
and
had
little

for
want
and
rags
as
a
cruel

such
as
they
sometimes
seem
in

,
but
held
them
a
mark

and

<EOS>
and
it
was
idleness
and
vice
that
brought
burdens
on
the

.
<EOS>
To
Hetty

"
parish
"
was
next
to
the
prison

,
and
to
ask
anything
of
strangers
 
to
beg
 
lay
in
the
same
far
-
off
hideous

of

that
Hetty
had
all
her
life
thought
it
impossible

.
<EOS>
But

,

HER

.
<EOS>
And

;
for
Hetty
had
the
luxurious

a
round

.
  
<EOS>
How
she
yearned
to
be
back

her

home
again
,
cherished
and

for
as

!
<EOS>
Her

about

now
;
she

;

.
<EOS>
Could

she
,

,
lying

,

and

some

<EOS>
It

her
locket

,

,

<EOS>
There

Adam

the

"
Remember

"

;

<EOS>
Those

,

,

had

!
<EOS>
She
had

in

ears

:
her

its

rings

lay

,
and

that
rested

was
something
too
hard
for
regretful

.
<EOS>
Yet
she
put
her
hands
up
to
her
ears
:
it
was
because

some
thin

rings
in

,
which
were
also
worth

.
<EOS>
Yes
,
she
could
surely
get
some

for
her

:
those
Arthur
had
given

must

great

.
<EOS>
The
landlord
and

had
been
good
to
her
;
perhaps
they
would
help
her
to
get
the
money
for

.
  
<EOS>
But
this
money
would
not
keep
her
long
.
<EOS>
What
should
she
do
when
it
was
gone
?
<EOS>
Where
should
she
go
?
<EOS>
The
horrible
thought
of
want
and
beggary
drove
her
once
to
think
she
would
go
back
to
her
uncle

aunt

to
forgive

and

.
<EOS>
But
she
shrank

again
,
as
she

.
<EOS>
She
could
never
endure
that

before
her

,

Mary
Burge
,
and

,

Broxton
,
and
everybody
who
knew

.
<EOS>
They
should
never
know
what
had
happened
to
her
.
<EOS>
What
could
she
do
?
<EOS>
She
would
go
away
from
Windsor
 
<EOS>
travel
again
as
she
had
done
the
last
week
,
and
get
among
the
flat
green
fields
with
the
high
hedges
<EOS>
round

,
where
nobody
could

;
and

,

,

,

in

.
<EOS>
Yes
,
she
would
get
away
from
Windsor
as
soon

possible
:
she

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>
With

something

something

<EOS>

The

<EOS>
Suppose

<EOS>
Dinah

<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
And

Hetty
,
poor
thing
 
<EOS>
a

,

.
<EOS>
They

she

.
<EOS>
And

"

.
  
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
Despair

,

.
  
<EOS>
Hetty
felt
that
no

;

.
<EOS>
No
;

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
  
<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
Religious

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
She

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
At

,

.
<EOS>
If

!
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
No

,

<EOS>
She

down
,
thinking

pool
in
every
hollow
before
she
came
to
it
,
till
her
limbs
were
weary
,
and
she
sat
down
to
rest
.
<EOS>
The
afternoon
was
far
advanced
,
and
the
leaden
sky
was
darkening
,
as
if
the
sun
were
setting
behind
it
.
<EOS>
After
a
little
while
Hetty
started
up
again
,
feeling
that
darkness
would
soon
come
on
;
and
she
must
put
off
finding
the
pool
till
to
-
morrow
,
and
make
her
way
to
some
shelter
for
the
night
.
<EOS>
She
had
quite
lost
her
way
in
the
fields
,
and
might
as
well
go
in
one
direction
as
another
,
for
aught
she
knew
.
<EOS>
She
walked
through
field
after
field
,
and
no
village
,
no
house
was
in
sight
;
but
there
,
at
the
corner
of
this
pasture
,
there
was
a
break
in
the
hedges
;
the
land
seemed
to
dip
down
a
little
,
and
two
trees
leaned
towards
each
other
across
the
opening
.
<EOS>
Hetty
's
heart
gave
a
great
beat
as
she
thought
there
must
be
a
pool
there
.
<EOS>
She
walked
towards
it
heavily
over
the
tufted
grass
,
with
pale
lips
and
a
sense
of
trembling
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
the
thing
were
come
in
spite
of
herself
,
instead
of
being
the
object
of
her
search
.
  
<EOS>
There
it
was
,
black
under
the
darkening
sky
:
<EOS>
no
motion
,
no
sound
near
.
<EOS>
She
set
down
her
basket
,
and
then
sank
down
herself
on
the
grass
,
trembling
.
<EOS>
The
pool
had
its
wintry
depth
now
:
by
the
time
it
got
shallow
,
as
she
remembered
the
pools
did
at
Hayslope
,
in
the
summer
,
no
one
could
find
out
that
it
was
her
body
.
<EOS>
But
then
there
was
her
basket
 
<EOS>
she
must
hide
that
too
.
<EOS>
She
must
throw
it
into
the
water
 
<EOS>
make
it
heavy
with
stones
first
,
and
then
throw
it
in
.
<EOS>
She
got
up
to
look
about
for
stones
,
and
soon
brought
five
or
six
,
which
she
laid
down
beside
her
basket
,
and
then
sat
down
again
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
need
to
hurry
 
<EOS>
there
was
all
the
night
to
drown
herself
in
.
<EOS>
She
sat
leaning
her
elbow
on
the
basket
.
<EOS>
She
was
weary
,
hungry
.
<EOS>
There
were
some
buns
in
her
basket
 
three
,
which
she
had
supplied
herself
with
at
the
place
where
she
ate
her
dinner
.
<EOS>
She
took
them
out
now
and
ate
them
eagerly
,
and
then
sat
still
again
,
looking
at
the
pool
.
<EOS>
The
soothed
sensation
that
came
over
her
from
the
satisfaction
of
her
hunger
,
and
this
fixed
dreamy
attitude
,
brought
on
drowsiness
,
and
presently
her
head
sank
down
on
her
knees
.
<EOS>
She
was
fast
asleep
.
  
<EOS>
When
she
awoke
it
was
deep
night
,
and
she
felt
chill
.
<EOS>
She
was
frightened
at
this
darkness
 
frightened
at
the
long
night
before
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
could
but
throw
herself
into
the
water
!
<EOS>
No
,
not
yet
.
<EOS>
She
began
to
walk
about
that
she
might
get
warm
again
,
as
if
she
would
have
more
resolution
then
.
<EOS>
Oh
how
long
the
time
was
in
that
darkness
!
<EOS>
The
bright
hearth
and
the
warmth
and
the
voices
of
home
,
the
secure
uprising
and
lying
down
,
the
familiar
fields
,
the
familiar
people
,
the

and
holidays
with
their
simple
joys
of
dress
and
feasting
 
all
the
sweets
of
her
young
life
rushed
before
her
now
,
and
she
seemed
to
be
stretching
her
arms
towards
them
across
a
great
gulf
.
<EOS>
She
set
her
teeth
when
she
thought
of
Arthur
.
<EOS>
She
cursed
him
,
without
knowing
what
her
cursing
would
do
.
<EOS>
She
wished
he
too
might
know
desolation
,
and
cold
,
and
a
life
of
shame
that
he
dared
not
end
by
death
.
  
<EOS>
The
horror
of
this
cold
,
and
darkness
,
and
solitude
 
out
of
all
human
reach
 
became
greater
every
long
minute
.
<EOS>
It
was
almost
as
if
she
were
dead
already
,
and
knew
that
she
was
dead
,
and
longed
to
get
back
to
life
again
.
<EOS>
But
no
:
she
was
alive
still
;
she
had
not
taken
the
dreadful
leap
.
<EOS>
She
felt
a
strange
contradictory
wretchedness
and
exultation
:
wretchedness
,
that
she
did
not
dare
to
face
death
;
exultation
,
that
she
was
still
in
life
 
that
she
might
yet
know
light
and
warmth
again
.
<EOS>
She
walked
backwards
and
forwards
to
warm
herself
,
beginning
to
discern
something
of
the
objects
around
her
,
as
her
eyes
became
accustomed
to
the
night
 
<EOS>
the
darker
line
of
the
hedge
,
the
rapid
motion
of
some
living
creature
 
perhaps
a
field
-
mouse
 
rushing
across
the
grass
.
<EOS>
She
no
longer
felt
as
if
the
darkness
hedged
her
in
.
<EOS>
She
thought
she
could
walk
back
across
the
field
,
and
get
over
the
stile
;
and
then
,
in
the
very
next
field
,
she
thought
she
remembered
there
was
a
hovel
of
furze
near
a
sheepfold
.
<EOS>
If
she
could
get
into
that
hovel
,
she
would
be
warmer
.
<EOS>
She
could
pass
the
night
there
,
for
<EOS>
that
was
what
Alick
did
at
Hayslope
in

-

.
<EOS>
The
thought
of
this
hovel
brought
the
energy
of
a
new
hope
.
<EOS>
She
took
up
her
basket
and
walked
across
the
field
,
but
it
was
some
time
before
she
got
in
the
right

for
the
stile
.
<EOS>
The
exercise
and
the
occupation
of
finding
the
stile
were
a

to
her
,
however
,
and
lightened
the

.
<EOS>
There
were
sheep
in
the
next
field
,
and
she
startled
a
group
as
she
set
down
her
basket
and
got
over
the
stile
;
and
the

their

comforted

,
for
it

her
that
her
impression
was
right
 
<EOS>
this
was
the
field
where
she
had
seen
the
hovel
,
for
it
was
the
field
where
the
sheep
were
.
<EOS>
Right
on
along
the
path
,
and
she
would
get
to
it
.
<EOS>
She
reached
the
opposite
gate
,
and
felt
her
way
along
its
rails
and
the
rails
of
the
sheep
-
fold
,
till
her
hand
encountered
the
pricking
of
the
gorsy
wall
.
<EOS>
Delicious
sensation
!
<EOS>
She
had
found
the
shelter
.
<EOS>
She
groped
her
way
,
touching
the
prickly
gorse
,
to
the
door
,
and
pushed
it
open
.
<EOS>
It
was
an
ill
-
smelling
close
place
,
but
warm
,
and
there
was
straw
on
the
ground
.
<EOS>
Hetty
sank
down
on
the
straw
with
a
sense
of
escape
.
<EOS>
Tears
came
 
<EOS>
she
had
never
shed
tears
before
since
she
left
Windsor
 
tears
and
sobs
of
hysterical
joy
that
she
had
still
hold
of
life
,
that
she
was
still
on
the
familiar

,
with
the
sheep
near

.
<EOS>
The
very
consciousness
of
her
own

was
a

to

:
she
turned
up
her

,
and

her

with
the

love
of
life
.
<EOS>
Soon

and

lulled

in

,
and
she

continually

,

at
the

of
the
pool
again
 
fancying
that
she
had
jumped
into
the
water
,
and
then
awaking

a

,
and
wondering
where
she
was
.
<EOS>
But
at
last
deep
dreamless
sleep
came
;
her

,
guarded
by
her
bonnet
,
found
a
pillow
against
the
gorsy
wall
,
and
the
poor

,
driven

and

between
two

,
found
the
one

that
was
possible
to
it
 
the

.
  
<EOS>
Alas
!
<EOS>
That

seems
to
end
the

has

.
<EOS>
It

as

those
dozen
dreams
had
only
passed
into
another
dream
 
that
she
was
in
the
hovel
,
and
her
aunt

.
<EOS>
She

under
her

's

,
and

.
<EOS>
There
was

,

in

the

early

through

.
<EOS>
And

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,

,

?
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
Hetty

than
she

done

her
momentary

under

.
<EOS>
She
felt
that
she
was
like

already
 
found

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
she

.
<EOS>
"
I
'm
travelling
 
north'ard
,
and
I
got
away

road
into

fields
,
and

.
<EOS>
Will

the
nearest

?
"
  
<EOS>
She
got
up
as

,
and

her

to

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Then

<EOS>
o

?

.

<EOS>
Y'ull

.

"

"

.

Anybody

,

'

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hetty

.
<EOS>
As

.
<EOS>

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

"
I

o
'

.
<EOS>
You

,
<EOS>

,

a

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
Another

had
risen
,
and
she
must

.
<EOS>
It

no

she
could
not

,
at

while
she
had
money

to

.
<EOS>
But

her

her
dread
of
that
time
when
her
money
would
be
all

;
she
would
have

,
and
she
would

,

.
<EOS>
The

in
life
she
had
felt
in

,
after

the

of
the
black
cold
death

pool
,
was
gone

.
<EOS>
Life
now
,
by
the
morning
light
,
with
the
impression
of
that
man
's
hard

look
at
her
,
was
as
full

dread
as
death
 
<EOS>
it
was
worse
;
it
was
a
dread
to
which
she
felt

,
from
which
she
shrank
and
shrank
as
she
did
from
the
black
pool
,
and
yet
could
find
no

.
  
<EOS>
She
took
out
her
money
from
her
purse
,
and
looked
at
it
.
<EOS>
She
had
still
two
-
and
-
twenty
shillings
;
it
would
serve
her
for
many
days
more
,
or
it
would
help
her
to
get
on
faster
to
Stonyshire
,
within
reach
of
Dinah
.
<EOS>
The
thought
of
Dinah
urged
itself
more
strongly
now
,
since
the
experience
of
the
night
had
driven
her
shuddering
imagination
away
from
the
pool
.
<EOS>
If
it
had
been
only
going
to
Dinah
 
<EOS>
if
nobody
besides
Dinah
would
ever
know
 
Hetty
could
have
made
up
her
mind
to
go
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
soft
voice
,
the
pitying
eyes
,
would
have
drawn
her
.
<EOS>
But
afterwards
the
other
people
must
know
,
and
she
could
no
more
rush
on
that

than
she
could

on
death
.
  
<EOS>
She
must
wander
on
and
on
,
and
wait
for
a
lower
depth
of
despair
to
give
her
courage
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
death
would
come
to
her
,
for
she
was
getting
less
and
less
able
to
bear
the
day
's
weariness
.
<EOS>
And
yet
 
such

,

towards
the
very
ends
we
dread
 
Hetty
,
when

,
asked
the

,

.
  
<EOS>
Poor

,
with

,

with

,
<EOS>
no

<EOS>
My

that
a

.
  
<EOS>
What

end
,

end

her
objectless

,
apart

all

,

,
clinging

the
hunted

?
  
<EOS>
God
preserve
you
and
me
from
being
the
beginners
of
such
misery
!
    
<EOS>
The
Quest
  
<EOS>
THE

's

Every

The
Tidings

<EOS>
The
Eve
of
the
Trial
  
<EOS>
AN
upper

in

,

in

one

on

.
<EOS>

,

.

.

"

<EOS>
The
Morning
of
the
Trial
  
<EOS>
AT
one
o'clock
the
next
day
,
Adam
was
alone
in
his
dull
upper
room
;
his
watch
lay
before
him
on
the
table
,
as
if
he
were
counting
the
long
minutes
.
<EOS>
He
had
no
knowledge
of
what
was
likely
to
be
said
by
the
witnesses
on
the
trial
,
for
he
had
shrunk
from
all
the
particulars
connected
with
Hetty
's
arrest
and
accusation
.
<EOS>
This
brave
active
man
,
who
would
have
hastened
towards
any
danger
or
toil
to
rescue
Hetty
from
an
apprehended
wrong
or
misfortune
,
felt
himself
powerless
to
contemplate
irremediable
evil
and
suffering
.
<EOS>
The
susceptibility
which
would
have
been
an
impelling
force
where
there
was
any
possibility
of
action
became
helpless
anguish
when
he
was
obliged
to
be
passive
,
or
else
sought
an
active
outlet
in
the
thought
of
inflicting
justice
on
Arthur
.
<EOS>
Energetic
natures
,
strong
for
all
strenuous
deeds
,
will
often
rush
away
from
a
hopeless
sufferer
,
as
if
they
were
hard
-
hearted
.
<EOS>
It
is
the
overmastering
sense
of
pain
that
drives
them
.
<EOS>
They
shrink
by
an
ungovernable
instinct
,
as
they
would
shrink
from
laceration
.
<EOS>
Adam
had
brought
himself
to
think
of
seeing
Hetty
,
if
she
would
consent
to
see
him
,
because
he
thought
the
meeting
might
possibly
be
a
good
to
her
 
might
help
to
melt

this
terrible
hardness
they
told

of
.
<EOS>
If
she
saw
he
bore
her
no
ill

for
what
she
had
done
to
him
,
she
might

to

.
<EOS>
But
this
resolution
had
been
an
immense

<EOS>
he
trembled
at

of
seeing

changed
face
,
as

at
the
thought
of
the
surgeon
's
knife
,
and
he
chose
now

the
long

of
suspense
rather
than

what

the
more

of
witnessing
her
trial
.
  
<EOS>
Deep
unspeakable
suffering
may
well
be
called
a
baptism
,
a
regeneration
,
the
initiation
into
a
new

.
<EOS>
The

to
the
Invisible
<EOS>
Right
 
all

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

n't
send
for
a
doctor
,
for
there
seemed
no
need
.
<EOS>
I
told
the
mother
in
the
day
-

she
must

,
and

,

.
<EOS>
She

,
by
and

,
but

-

.
<EOS>
She

,
but

,

.
<EOS>
She
said
she
felt

;

.
<EOS>
But

,

I

mind

I

,

.
<EOS>
I

about

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I
did

;

;

,
and

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She
'd

....
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>

'd

"
  
<EOS>
The

;

.
<EOS>
Hetty
could
not

the
crime
 
<EOS>
her

must

her
baby
 
else
why
should

?
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
The

had

,

.
<EOS>
Babies
were
so

death
 
<EOS>
and
there
might

the

without

.
<EOS>
His

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

:

.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
This

,

.
<EOS>
He

:
  
"
My

John
Olding
.
<EOS>
I

,

,

.
<EOS>
A

,

,

Coppice
,

I

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>

;

.

a

.
<EOS>
She
'd

.
"
  
<EOS>
Adam
had
given

.
<EOS>
He
had
hidden

,

.
<EOS>
It

:
<EOS>
Hetty

;

.
<EOS>
He

,

unconscious
that
Mr.
Irwine
was
in

,
telling

.
<EOS>
This

,

a

.
  
<EOS>
At

lifted

his

,
for
there
was
a

.
<EOS>
The
judge
had
addressed
the
jury
,
and
they
were
retiring
.
<EOS>
The
decisive
moment
was
not
far
off
Adam
<EOS>
felt
a

that
would
not

Hetty
,
but
she
had
long

her
blank

.
<EOS>
All

were
strained
to

at

,
but
she
stood
like

.
  
<EOS>
'
There
was
a
mingled

,

,

court

.
<EOS>
The

,
and
every

had

.
<EOS>
Adam
sat

,
but

that
were
right

<EOS>
the

.
<EOS>
The

was
too

for
Adam
to
take
in
outward
objects
until
some

.
  
<EOS>
It

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

sublime
 
that

which

that

.
<EOS>
Deeper

seemed

,

,
while

's

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Guilty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was

every

,
but

some

that

.
<EOS>
Still

of

court
was

.
<EOS>
The

of
her

stood

her

.
<EOS>
Even

,
to
distant

,
had
not

,
but

who

.
  
<EOS>
The

was
less

until

,

.
<EOS>
Then

,

.
<EOS>
If

.
<EOS>
The
judge

,
"
Hester
Sorrel
....
"
  
<EOS>
The

's

,

.
<EOS>
Adam

not

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

"
and

,
"
a

.
<EOS>
It

's

.
<EOS>
Adam

and

.
<EOS>
But

could
not

:
she
had

,
and
was

.
   
<EOS>
Arthur
's
Return
 
<EOS>
When
Arthur
Donnithorne
landed
at
Liverpool
and
read
the
letter
from
his
Aunt
Lydia
,
briefly
announcing
his
grand
-
father
's
death
,
his
first
feeling
was
,
"
Poor
Grandfather
!
<EOS>

where
his
Aunt
Lydia
was
expecting
him
.
<EOS>
Aunt
Lydia
was
the
only

in
the
house
who
knew
nothing
about
Hetty
.
<EOS>
Her
sorrow
as
a
maiden
daughter
was
unmixed
with
any
other

than
those
of
anxiety
about
funeral

and
her
own
future
lot
;
and
,

women
,
she

for

father
who
had
made
her
life
important
,
all
the
more
because
she
had
a
secret

that
there
was
little

for
him
in
other

.
  
<EOS>
But
Arthur
kissed
her
tearful

more

than
he
had

in
his
life
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
Dear
Aunt
,
"
he
said
affectionately
,
as

,
"
YOUR
loss
is
the
greatest
of
all
,
but
you
must
tell
me
how
to
try

make

to

all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
was

,
Arthur
,
"
poor
Miss
Lydia
began
,

,

.
<EOS>
When

,

:
  
"
Now
,
Aunt
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,

Mills
?
<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

.

<EOS>
On

,

Arthur

,

,

.
<EOS>
Pym
was

,

,

<EOS>
The

.
   
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

...
   
<EOS>
Arthur

.
<EOS>

he

,

.
<EOS>
Mills

,

,

<EOS>

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

I

<EOS>

"

,

.
    
<EOS>
In
the
Prison
  
NEAR
sunset
that

an

of

,

.
<EOS>
The

,
but
the

stood

,
looking
down

,
when

was

by

sweet
clear
woman
's

,
saying
,
"
Can
I
get
into

prison
,
if

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
turned
his

and

fixedly

for
a

without

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
seen
you
before
,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
Do
you
remember

on
the

at
Hayslope

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,

.
<EOS>
Are

that

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

death

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

;

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
What
!
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Dinah
mechanically

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
As

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
The

,

,
through

small

enough
to

.
<EOS>
Dinah

,
hesitating
to

because
Hetty
might
be
asleep
,
and
looking

.
<EOS>
Then
she
said
,

,
"
Hetty
!
"
  
<EOS>
There

a
slight
movement
perceptible
in
Hetty
's
frame
 
<EOS>
a
start
such
as
might

by

but

.
<EOS>
Dinah

,

,
"
Hetty
...
<EOS>
it
's
Dinah
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Again

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Hetty
...
<EOS>
Dinah

.
"
  
<EOS>
After

,

.
<EOS>
The

:

,

.
<EOS>
Dinah

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Hetty

fixed

's

at

,
and
gazes
,
and

aloof
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'm

to

,
Hetty
 
not

to

to

.

<EOS>
Slowly

,

was

.
  
<EOS>
They

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

<EOS>
IT

sudden

.
  
<EOS>
All
Stoniton
had
heard
of
Dinah
Morris
,
the
young

woman
who
had
brought
the

to

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
But

was
hardly

.
<EOS>
When

had
caught

vast

in

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Close

,
Hetty
,
"
Dinah
said
,
"
and
let

without

God
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
in

,

,
for

that

and

as
the

.
  
<EOS>
Dinah

awe
 
she

the
fatal
spot
,

,

at

.
<EOS>
Hetty

with

,
and
they

.
  
<EOS>
But

not

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

hot

,
but

;
the

,

<EOS>
but
what

.
<EOS>
See
,
he

something

<EOS>
he

.
  
<EOS>
The

:

Donnithorne
,

a

won
release

.
    
<EOS>
Another
Meeting
in
the
Wood
  
<EOS>
THE

,

by
Donnithorne

:

.

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
At
the
Hall
Farm
  
THE
first
autumnal

of
1801
 
more
than

months
after

of
Adam
and
Arthur
in

was
on
the
yard

the
Hall

;
and

-

was
in

,
for

was
that
hour
of
the
day
when
the
cows
were

.
<EOS>
No
wonder

patient

wrong

,
for

of
the
bull
-
dog
was

with
more

which
the
timid

,

with

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

Poor

.
  
<EOS>
There

.

and
then
hesitated
,
looking
at

with

.
<EOS>
It

there
was
among

.
<EOS>

,

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,

,

,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>
Seth
was
hurt
.
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"

,

"

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

'

.

"

<EOS>

war

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
Lisbeth

,

Seth
in

Adam
's

.
<EOS>
He
consoled

,

's
trouble

Lisbeth
had

,
and
that

this

.
<EOS>
Even

,

.
  
<EOS>
Seth

,
and

<EOS>

,
till

when

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
  
<EOS>
Sunday

,

.
<EOS>
Moreover

better

for
her
sons
 
very

often
away

and
the

in
the
clean

,
<EOS>
the

in

,
her

seated

in

,
doing

,
so
that

and

,

Gyp
,
rather

,
poked

up
between

all

made
poor
Lisbeth
's

.
  
<EOS>
The
book
Adam
most
often

on

was
his
large

,
and
this

lay

in

;
for
he

there
in
spite
of
the
fire
,
because
he
knew
his
mother
liked
to

with

,
and
it

when

in

.
<EOS>
You
would
have
liked

Adam

his
Bible
.
<EOS>
He
never
opened
it
on

,
and
so

came
to

as

book
,

,

.
<EOS>

,

the

ready
to

,

.
<EOS>
Sometimes

moved
in
semi

<EOS>
it

,

's

<EOS>
something

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
For

<EOS>
Lisbeth

,

.
<EOS>
This

,

Surely

<EOS>
Leisure
is
gone
 
<EOS>
gone
where
the

-

are
gone
,
and
the

-

,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
Ingenious
philosophers
tell
you
,
perhaps
,
that
the
great
work
of

-

is
to

for

.
<EOS>
Do
not

:
it
only

for

to

.
<EOS>
Even
idleness
is
eager
now
 
eager
for

;
prone
to

,
art

,

,
and

;

and

.
<EOS>
Old
Leisure
was
quite
a
different
personage
.
<EOS>
He
only
read
one
newspaper
,
innocent
of
leaders
,
and
was
free
from
that
periodicity
of
sensations
which
we
call
post
-
time
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
contemplative
,
rather
stout
gentleman
,
of
excellent
digestion
;
of
quiet
perceptions
,
undiseased
by
hypothesis
;
happy
in
his
inability
to
know
the
causes
of
things
,
preferring
the
things
themselves
.
<EOS>
He
lived
chiefly
in
the
country
,
among
pleasant
seats
and
homesteads
,
and
was
fond
of
sauntering
by
the
fruit

tree
wall
and
scenting
the
apricots
when
they
were
warmed
by
the
morning

,
or
of

under
the
orchard

at
noon
,
when
the
summer
pears
were
falling
.
<EOS>
He
knew
nothing
of
weekday
services
,
and
thought
none
the
worse
of
the
Sunday
sermon
if
it
allowed
him
to
sleep
from
the
text
to
the
blessing
;
liking
the
afternoon
service
best
,
because
the
prayers
were
the
shortest
,
and
not
ashamed
to
say

;
for
he
had
an
easy
,
jolly
conscience
,
broad
-
backed
like
himself
,
and
able
to
carry
a
great
deal
of
beer
or
port

wine
,
not
being
made

by
doubts
and

and
lofty

.
<EOS>
Life
was
not
a
task
to
him
,
but
a
sinecure
.
<EOS>
He
fingered
the
guineas
in
his
pocket
,
and
ate
his
dinners
,
and
slept
the
sleep
of
the
irresponsible
,
for
had
he
not
kept
up
his
character
by
going
to
church
on
the
Sunday
afternoons
?
  
<EOS>
Fine
old
Leisure
!
<EOS>
Do
not
be
severe
upon
him
,
and
judge
him
by
our
modern
standard
.
<EOS>
He
never
went
to
Exeter
Hall
,
or
heard
a
popular

,
or
read

for
the
Times

Resartus
.
    
<EOS>
The
Harvest
Supper
  
<EOS>
As
Adam
was
going
homeward
,
on
Wednesday

,
in
the
six

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
The
Meeting
on
the
Hill
  
ADAM
understood
Dinah
's

to
go
away
,
and
drew

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

'd

,

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And

a

,

.
<EOS>
She
wants

old

.
<EOS>
And
I
've
no

.
<EOS>
She
's
told
me
what
her
mind
is
,
and
she
's
not
a
woman
to
say
one
thing
and
mean
another
.
<EOS>
I
'll
wait
patiently
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
That
was
Adam
's
wise
resolution
,
and
it
throve
excellently
for
the
first
two
or
three
weeks
on
the
nourishment
it
got
from
the
remembrance
of
Dinah
's
confession
that
Sunday

.
<EOS>
There
is
a
wonderful
amount
of
sustenance
in
the
first
few
words
of
love
.
<EOS>
But
towards
the
middle
of
October
the
resolution
began
to
dwindle
perceptibly
,
and
showed
dangerous
symptoms
of
exhaustion
.
<EOS>
The
weeks
were
unusually
long
:
Dinah
must
surely
have
had
more
than
enough
time
to
make
up
her
mind
.
<EOS>
Let
a
woman
say

she
will
after

,

little
too

with
that
first
draught
<EOS>
she
offers
him
to
care
much
about

taste
of

second
.
<EOS>
He
treads
the
earth
with
a
very
elastic
step
as
he
walks
away
from
her
,
and
makes
light
of
all
difficulties
.
<EOS>
But
that
sort
of
glow
dies
out
:
memory
gets
sadly
diluted
with
time
,
and
is
not
strong
enough
to
revive
us
.
<EOS>
Adam
was
no
longer
so
confident
as
he
had
been
.
<EOS>
He
began
to
fear
that
perhaps
Dinah
's
old
life
would
have
too
strong
a
grasp
upon

for
any

.
<EOS>
If

had
not
felt
this
,
she
would
surely
have
written
to
him
to

some
comfort
;
but
it
appeared
that
she
held
it
right

.
<EOS>
As
Adam
's

,
and
he
thought

must
write

.
<EOS>
He
must
ask

not

.
<EOS>
He

,
but
the

burnt

,

.
<EOS>
It

,
for
her

reconciled

her

.
  
<EOS>
You
perceive
how
it
was
:
<EOS>
Adam
was

for
the
sight
of
Dinah
,
and
when

a

stage
,
a

is
likely
to
still
it

put

future
in

.
  
<EOS>
But

?
<EOS>
Dinah
could

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She
must

expect

would
go
before
long
.
<EOS>
By

this

,
for

were
precious

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
What

!
<EOS>
He

,

Oakbourne

Marriage
